Corsi et al. 2011 - Is the polarization index a valid measure of loyalty for evaluating changes over time.pdf
Measure,Type / Derivation,How it is used in the article,Evidence in the text (verbatim excerpts)
Market Share (MS),Basic behavioural/market‐level indicator,Used as a benchmark variable and explanatory factor for other loyalty measures
column2: variations in MS across two three-year periods are shown and contrasted with changes in loyalty indices.,"“products or brands with higher market share (MS) tend also to have a higher PF, a higher SCR and a higher r”
column3: Table I reports MS for each attribute level in 2003-2005 and 2006-2008."

column1: Purchase Frequency (PF),Classical Brand Performance Measure (BPM),"Calculated for every attribute level (price, format, quality) in each period to show changes in buying intensity
column2: later compared with w to highlight possible bias over time.",“the purchase frequency (PF)… provide information on consumers’ behavioural loyalty levels”
column3: Table I columns ‘Purchase frequency (litres)’ list PF values for 2003-2005 and 2006-2008.

column1: Share of Category Requirements (SCR),Classical BPM,Computed for every attribute level
column2: used to examine how much of a buyer’s total category volume is assigned to a specific level
column3: compared across periods and against w.,“the share of category requirements (SCR)… provide information on consumers’ behavioural loyalty levels”
column4: Table I columns ‘SCR (%)’ show SCR for both periods.

column1: Repeat Purchase Rate (r),Derived BPM (function of MS and w),Applied to each attribute level via Equation (3) to estimate the conditional probability of a repeat choice
column2: trends contrasted with those of MS and w.,Formula (3) “r_i = MS_i + w 2 MS_i × w …”
column3: Table I columns ‘Repeat rate (%)’ present r for 2003-2005 and 2006-2008.

column1: Polarization Index (w),Independent loyalty metric,Core measure used to demonstrate unbiased detection of loyalty changes over time
column2: marginal w values (BBD) and the category benchmark (wc) are calculated for all attributes and compared across periods.,"“the polarization index (w) represents a valid loyalty measure for evaluating changes over time.”
column3: “By comparison, w provides a valid and useful analysis of the ways in which loyalty evolves over time.”"

column1: Category Polarization Index (wc) (also called DMD value),Benchmark polarization for the whole category (derived from Dirichlet Multinomial Distribution),Serves as the reference loyalty level
column2: individual attribute-level w values are judged as showing ‘excess’ or ‘low’ loyalty relative to wc.,"“Before estimating all the marginal w, the benchmark value – also called category polarization index (wc) or DMD value – needs to be calculated.”
column3: Table II column ‘DMD (wc)’ lists wc for each attribute in both periods."

column1: Delgado-Santos et al. 2022 - A Survey of Privacy Vulnerabilities of Mobile Device Sensors.pdf
Metric,Como é usado no texto,Evidência no texto
Accuracy,"Avaliar desempenho de classificadores (demografia, atividade, saúde etc.)","""They achieved an accuracy of 96 % using the Random Forest (RF) method.""  "
AUROC (Area Under ROC),Mede qualidade de curvas ROC
column2: usado em biometria/saúde/mood,"""...achieving an average Area Under the Receiver Operating Characteristic (AUROC) curve of over 99.0 %.""  "

column1: Equal Error Rate (EER),Ponto de igualdade entre FAR e FRR para biometria/privacidade,"""EERbefore ≈ 1 %   EERafter ≈ 28 %""  "
Error Rate / ERR,Percentual de erros do classificador,"""percentage error rate of 24.23 % for gender and 5.39 % for age.""  "
F1-score,Combina precisão e revocação
column2: usado para avaliar modelos após sanitização,"""F1-score SA before = 72.58 %   F1-score SA after = 52.99 %""  "

column1: Kullback-Leibler distance / KL-Score,Distância entre distribuições
column2: empregado para comparar rotas/localização,"""...obtaining a Kullback-Leibler distance of 0.00057 in the case of a taxi journey.""  "

column1: Probability of Success,Probabilidade de quebra de privacidade ou ataque bem-sucedido,"""0.45 % probability of success @ FAR = 10 %""  "
False Acceptance Rate (FAR),Taxa de falsa aceitação em sistemas biométricos,"""@ FAR = 10 %""  "
Task Assignment Success Rate (TASR),Mede sucesso de alocação de tarefas em crowdsensing com DP,"""TASR ≈ 80 %""  "
Hiding Failure (HF),Porção de padrões sensíveis ainda visíveis após sanitização,"""HF = 0/3 attribute disclosure""  "
Correct Overall Classification Rate (COCR),Taxa global correta em reconhecimento facial após redução de atributos,"""COCRbefore = 94.7 %   COCRafter = 64.7 %""  "
Confidence Interval Width,Amplitude do intervalo usada como métrica de privacidade/precisão,"""The confidence interval width indicates the amount of privacy...""  "

Euclidean Distance (expected estimation error),Erro de estimação em privacidade de localização,"""...by computing the expected distance between the true location and the estimated location using a distance metric, such as the Euclidean distance [155].""  "

Size of Uncertainty Region,Área mínima onde o usuário pode estar sem ser identificado,"""the size of the uncertainty region denotes the minimal size of the region to which it is possible to narrow down the position...""  "

Coverage of Sensitive Region,Sobreposição entre regiões sensíveis e região de incerteza,"""the coverage of sensitive region evaluates how a user’s sensitive regions overlap with the uncertainty region [56].""  "
Maximum Tracking Time,Tempo máximo durante o qual o alvo pode ser seguido com êxito,"""...by computing the maximum tracking time [148]""  "
Mean Time to Confusion,Tempo médio até que o atacante perca o rastro do usuário,"""...or the mean time to confusion [82].""  "

Cross-Entropy,Mede similaridade entre distribuição estimada e real para privacidade,"""the degree of privacy protection is quantified by cross-entropy ... of the estimated and the true data distribution""  "
Cumulative Entropy,Entropia acumulativa usada em rotas para privacidade de localização,"""A cumulative formulation of entropy was defined in [92] in the context of location privacy...""  "
Entropy,Incerteza de variáveis
column2: base para várias métricas de privacidade,"""In the field of information theory, entropy describes the degree of uncertainty associated to the outcome of a random variable [154].""  "

column1: Mutual Information,Quantidade de informação comum entre variáveis
column2: menor valor = mais privacidade,"""Mutual information ... provides a measure of the quantity of information common to two random variables...""  "

column1: Conditional Privacy Loss,Perda de privacidade condicionada à informação liberada,"""conditional privacy loss [22] ... considers the ratio between true data distribution and the amount of information provided...""  "
Inherent Privacy,Métrica baseada em entropia contando possíveis saídas após adivinhações,"""Inherent privacy represents another example of metric derived from the definition of entropy...""  "
k-Anonymity,Garante que cada registro é indistinguível de pelo menos k-1 outros,"""k-Anonymity is independent of the information extraction technique and it quantifies the degree of privacy ...""  "
m-Invariance,Extensão de k-anonymity para múltiplas publicações do mesmo conjunto,"""m-invariance modifies k-anonymity to allow for multiple, different releases of the same dataset.""  "

Performance_Metric,Usage_in_Text,Evidence_from_Text

Critical Success Factors (KSF),Utilizado como indicador de desempenho de parceiros em redes de negócios colaborativas para medir o sucesso crítico de cada parceiro.,"“They focus on identifying indicators to measure the performance of partners in a collaborative business network, such as critical success factors (KSF)…”."

Key Performance Factors (KPF),Indicador empregado para avaliar fatores chave de desempenho dos parceiros dentro da rede colaborativa.,"“…identifying indicators to measure the performance of partners in a collaborative business network, such as … key performance factors (KPF)…”."

Key Performance Indicators (KPI),Métricas usadas tanto na definição de metas de sustentabilidade dos Product-Service Systems (PSS) quanto na avaliação do desempenho de parceiros.,1) “…key performance indicators (KPI).”  2) “Goals are set using KPIs measured using specific assessment techniques…”.

Confidence Values,Valores inseridos no sistema TrustSEv para avaliar e monitorar a confiança nos serviços prestados pelos parceiros.,“…entering confidence values and confidence level… evaluate the sustainable trust value and trust level…”.
Confidence Level,Nível de confiança calculado pelo TrustSEv para indicar o grau de confiança em cada parceiro.,“…entering confidence values and confidence level…”.
Sustainable Trust Value,Valor calculado no TrustSEv que representa a sustentabilidade da confiança ao longo do tempo.,“…evaluate the sustainable trust value and trust level…”.
Trust Level,"Indicador que expressa o nível de confiança global em um parceiro ou VO, usado para decisões de continuidade ou ajuste.",“…evaluate the sustainable trust value and trust level…”.
Target Goals,Metas futuras previstas no TrustSEv contra as quais o desempenho/confiança será comparado em períodos subsequentes.,“…forecasting target goals for the next evaluation period…”.

Life Cycle Assessment (LCA),Técnica de avaliação usada para medir o impacto ambiental (pilar ecológico) e servir de base para KPIs de sustentabilidade.,"“Goals are set using KPIs measured using specific assessment techniques (i.e., Life Cycle Assessment LCA…)”."

Life Cycle Cost Assessment (LCCA),Método associado aos KPIs para quantificar o custo ao longo do ciclo de vida e compor a avaliação econômica da sustentabilidade.,"“…specific assessment techniques (i.e., … Life Cycle Cost Assessment LCCA …)”."

Social Life Cycle Assessment (SLCA),Ferramenta de avaliação social integrada aos KPIs para medir impactos sociais e sustentar a análise de sustentabilidade.,"“…specific assessment techniques (i.e., … SLCA Social Life Cycle Assessment) …”."

Sustainability Assessment (SA),"Valor único resultante da normalização das avaliações LCA, LCCA e SLCA, utilizado para otimizar a sustentabilidade dentro do VO.",“Sustainability Assessment (SA) unique allows the analysis and optimization of sustainability within the VO”.

Score,"Pontuação calculada por ferramenta de seleção que avalia membros da VO com base em critérios, facilitando comparação e decisão.","“Finally, a calculation tool is proposed for a faster member evaluation based on the criteria and score obtained.”"

column2: usado na decomposição do TCO.,"""Considering revenues by complementary investments made during the life-cycle as well as interest expenses, the Total Monetary Profit (II) can be calculated."""

column1: Total Monetary Profit III,Lucro monetário após dedução de impostos sobre renda
column2: etapa posterior na decomposição do TCO.,"""By charging tax payments on income, the Total Monetary Profit (III) can be reported."""

column1: Total Calculatory Profit,Lucro calculatório após acrescer custo de oportunidade (juros calculatórios) e ajustes fiscais
column2: valor final usado para apresentar o TCO.,"""This Total Calculatory Profit finally represents the Total Costs of Ownership calculated on the basis of VOFI."""

column1: Net Funding Value,"Indicador de verificação que deve zerar a cada período no VOFI, garantindo equilíbrio entre entradas e saídas de caixa.","""As a check-up, the net funding value, which is defined as the accounting balance of all out- and in-payments, should be zero."""
Net Balance,Saldo líquido do investimento em cada período
column2: permite monitorar o valor do investimento ao longo do ciclo de vida.,"""…the net balance of the total investment. By this algorithm the value of an investment … can be monitored during the whole life-cycle simply by observing the net balance in each relevant period."""

column1: r_GK (ROI dinâmico),Versão dinâmica do ROI obtida a partir das planilhas VOFI
column2: serve para comparar a taxa de retorno efetiva do projeto com a taxa de referência.,"Figura 9: fórmula “”rGK ROI, dynamic”” e texto associado ""Out-tasking is financially profitable, if rGK > kTarget""."

column1: k (Capital Costs Ratio / kTarget),Taxa mínima de atratividade (custo de capital) usada como benchmark para decidir se o ROI dinâmico r_GK é aceitável.,"Figura 9: “”k Capital Costs Ratio”” e sentença ""Out-tasking is financially profitable, if rGK > kTarget""."
Vimala Rani and Mathirajan 2020 - Performance evaluation of due-date based dispatching rules in dynamic scheduling of diffusion furnace.pdf
Medidor_de_Performance,Como é usado no texto,Evidência no texto (trecho entre aspas)
Total Weighted Tardiness (TWT),"Objetivo de otimização a ser minimizado
column2: empregado nos modelos matemáticos, nos algoritmos heurísticos e na avaliação comparativa.","“...to optimize the due-date based scheduling objectives: Total weighted tardiness, on-time delivery rate, total earliness/lateness, and maximum lateness.”"

column1: On-time Delivery Rate (OTD rate),Objetivo de otimização a ser maximizado
column2: calculado como a razão entre jobs entregues no prazo e total de jobs.,“On-time delivery (OTD) rate is aiming to complete maximum number of jobs on or before its due-date. It can be defined as out of ‘N’ jobs how many jobs are completed on or before its due-date.”

column1: Total Earliness/Lateness (TE/L),Objetivo de otimização a ser minimizado
column2: soma dos desvios absolutos entre tempo de conclusão e due-date.,“Total earliness/lateness (TE/L) is sum of the absolute deviations of completion times from the due-date of all jobs.”

column1: Maximum Lateness (Lmax),Objetivo de otimização a ser minimizado
column2: pior atraso entre todos os jobs.,“Lmax is the maximum lateness among all jobs. Minimizing the maximum lateness is in a sense equivalent to minimizing the worst performance of the schedule.”

column1: Tardiness de um job (Tj),Mede o atraso individual (parte da função-objetivo TWT e da variável UPj).,“Tardiness of a job ‘j’ (Tj) can be defined as how much late the job ‘j’ is processed as compared to the due-date...”
Weighted Tardiness de um job (WTj),Produto do peso do job pelo seu tardiness
column2: somado gera o TWT.,“The weighted tardiness of the job ‘j’ (WTj) can be defined as WTj = Wj × Tj”

column1: Lateness de um job (Lj),Desvio (positivo ou negativo) entre conclusão e due-date
column2: usado para calcular Lmax.,“where Lj is lateness of the job ‘j’.”

column1: Earliness/Lateness de um job (ELj),Desvio absoluto individual (positivo para antecipação ou atraso)
column2: somado forma o TE/L.,“ELj ≥ | CTj − DDj | ... Constraint (21) is used to compute the dependent variable earliness/lateness (EL).”

column1: Unit Penalty (UPj),Indicador (0/1) de job tardio
column2: somado para contar número de atrasos no cálculo do OTD rate.,"“UPj ≥ min (1, Tj) ... used to assign the unit penalty to each tardy job.”"

column1: Indicador de entrega no prazo (OTDj),Variável binária (1 se job on-time) usada para compor OTD rate.,“OTDj = 1 if CTj ≤ DDj
column2: 0 Otherwise.”

column1: Relative Percentage Deviation (RPD),Métrica de desvio percentual de uma solução em relação ao benchmark por instância.,“we compute the relative percentage deviation (RPD) w.r.t. benchmark solution (BS) using Eq. (25).”
Average Relative Percentage Deviation (ARPD),Média dos RPDs em várias instâncias
column2: usada para comparar variantes heurísticas.,"“Next, compute the average of RPD (ARPD) for each variants of GHA-DDR over the number of problem instances...”"

column1: Friedman Rank / Friedman Test,Estatística não-paramétrica para verificar diferenças significativas entre variantes de algoritmos.,“This study conducts Friedman test to determine whether there are any significant differences among the twenty variants of GHA-DDR.”
Nemenyi Multiple Comparison Test,Teste post-hoc baseado nas estatísticas de Friedman
column2: compara pares de algoritmos via p-value.,"“...we conducts Nemenyi post hoc test, which does pair-wise comparison of the twenty variants on the performance...”"

column1: Liu et al. 2010 - Integration of decision support systems to improve decision support performance.pdf
Performance_Measure,How_it_is_used_in_the_text,Evidence_in_the_Text
Decision Efficiency,Desired improvement through integration of DSS,“…not only for improvement of the efficiency … of the decisions…” (Introduction)
Decision Effectiveness,Desired improvement through integration of DSS,“…not only for improvement of the … effectiveness of the decisions…” (Introduction)
Cognitive Workload Reduction,Goal of presentation integration,“Presentation integration aims at reducing user’s cognitive load …” (Sect 2.5)
Data/Information Consistency,Primary goal of data-information integration,“The goal of data and information integration is to obtain consistent information for consistent decisions…” (Sect 2.1)
Non-Redundancy of Data/Info,Property of well-integrated data management,Table 1 lists ‘Non-redundancy’ as an integration property: “…Components have little duplicate data/info….”
Interoperability,Property and target state of integrated components,Table 1 lists ‘Interoperability’ and later: “…well-integrated IDSS should use the same metaphors and mental models.”
Synchronisation,Required to keep components aligned,Table 1 lists ‘Synchronisation’ and the need for “…informing each other of changes they make to the data/info.”
Return on Investment (ROI),Evidence of performance benefit of IDSS,“…benefits of IDSS have been clearly manifested through tangible returns to investment …” (Sect 3)
Cost Savings,Quantitative benefit observed in organisations,“…and cost savings in organisations over many years.” (Sect 3)
Competitive Advantage,Business performance benefit of data-mining-enhanced IDSS,“…can provide significant competitive advantage to an organisation.” (Sect 3.2)
Reduction of Over-confidence,Behavioural performance gain of model-based IDSS,"“Prominence effects, overconfidence and other biases are reduced for managers who use model-based IDSS…” (Sect 2.2)"
Reduction of Prominence Effects,Same as above – bias reduction metric,Same sentence as above (Sect 2.2)

Active Interaction / Activeness,Performance feature added by intelligent agents,"“…weak performance of traditional DSS, i.e. its passiveness … Agents … for developing active, communicative and co-operative IDSS.” (Sect 3.3)"
Scalability,System-level performance enabled by Web technology,“…Web technology promotes IDSS for … scalability … ” (Fig 3 caption & Sect 3.4)
Openness,System-level performance enabled by Web technology,“…Internet and Web technology has presented a new world to IDSS in the sense that Web is … open …” (Sect 3.4)
Distribution/Global Access,Reach of decision support services,“…global access to decision support functions … to any stakeholders over Internet
column2: ” (Sect 3.4)

column1: Engel et al. 2022 - SLA-aware operational efficiency in AI-enabled service chains - challenges ahead.pdf
Performance_Metric,How_It_Is_Used (context in the paper),Textual_Evidence (exact quotation)

Operational Key Performance Indicators (KPIs),"Cross-client, organization-level measures that feed AI models driving core business processes and are optimised for global operational efficiency.",“…advanced analytics and artificial intelligence (AI) based on detailed monitored data from core operational information systems oftentimes provide crucial information for controlling data-driven decision-making… Often includes KPIs that monitor business processes in the enterprise.”
Service Level Indicator (SLI) – generic,Customer-specific quantitative measure forming the basis of each SLA
column2: contrasted with organisation-wide KPIs.,“Service level indicators (SLIs) are carefully defined quantitative measures of some aspect of the level of service that is provided.”

column1: Service Level Objective (SLO),Target/threshold value attached to an SLI
column2: (non-)compliance triggers penalties or rewards and is predicted by SLA analytics.,"“In the case of SLO misses (i.e., SLA non-compliance), A is responsible for paying penalties to its customers.”"

column1: Service availability (%),"Engagement-specific SLI measuring availability within given time-windows, units and guarantee intervals.",Table 1 example: “Service #1 – Service availability < 99.9 % … Service #3 – Service availability < 98 %”
Service uptime (%),"Alternative SLI for availability with different semantics (24 × 7 window, monthly reporting).",Table 1 example: “Service #2 – Service uptime < 98 % … 24×7 … Monthly”
Incident resolution time,KPI/SLA metric measuring time to resolve an incident
column2: semantics differ per customer because of different severity classifications.,“…customer-specific SLIs for incident resolution time defined in the corresponding formal SLA documents are based on custom metrics using the arbitrary priority classes of each customer…”

column1: Average incident resolution time,Performance KPI used by provider A to compare internal vs. outsourced 1st-level teams.,"“…various performance-related KPIs for the outsourced teams may differ from the internal ones (e.g., average incident resolution time).”"

Krumeich et al. 2016 - Prescriptive Control of Business Processes - New ... redictive Analytics of Big Data in the Process Manufacturing Industry.pdf
Performance_Indicator,Usage_in_Text,Evidence_in_Text

Key Performance Indicators (KPI),Generic umbrella for metrics that have to be minimised or maximised when the prescriptive controller chooses the best process option.,“…to minimise or maximise certain key performance indicators.” (Abstract)

Cost Savings,Stated as a desired outcome of applying predictive / prescriptive analytics to production processes.,"“…would contribute to cost savings, productivity and product quality improvements…” (Sect. 1.2)"

Productivity,Named together with cost savings and quality as a central performance goal for process optimisation.,"“…would contribute to cost savings, productivity and product quality improvements …” (Sect. 1.2)"

Product Quality (QU – Quality Units),Used as concrete numerical quality measure of intermediate and final products in the motivating scenario.,“…final products of type D with a quality of at least 90 quality units (QU)… resulting intermediate products C with a quality of 70 QU…” (Sect. 3.1)

Defect Rate / Timely Discovery of Defects,Reducing or detecting defects early is mentioned as a performance objective.,“…as well as to a timely discovery of defects within process executions.” (Sect. 1.2)
Cycle Time / Time Consumption,Explicitly introduced as KPI a in the example
column2: shorter cycle time is a performance target.,“…KPI a (time consumption)… the conditional probabilities… will be significantly different …” (Sect. 3.3.3)

column1: Resource Consumption,Named as criterion that prescriptive analytics tries to minimise when choosing an execution sequence.,“What is the best execution sequence … in order to minimise the overall resource consumption?” (Sect. 3.2)

Prediction Accuracy,Higher accuracy of forecasts is treated as a performance attribute of the analytical component itself.,“…the accuracy of predictions increases by the square root of the number of independent observations…” (Sect. 2.1)
Business Value Gained,Shown as the dependant variable that increases the earlier an event is predicted.,Figure 2 caption: “Business value gained through event prediction and proactive actions”
Event Likelihood / Probability,Probabilities of events (e.g. P(C)=0.67) are calculated and used as quantitative indicators for decision making.,“…P(C) evolves towards 0.67.” (Sect. 3.3.3)

Execution Probability of Process Branches,Probability distribution over alternative paths is treated as performance-relevant information.,“…the probability for P(C | CE1 and CE2) increases to 0.84 …” (Sect. 3.3.3)
Equipment Reliability / Machine Failures,"CBM aims at predicting failures
column2: reliability (time to failure, failure avoidance) is a performance measure.","“…predicts the time by which failure may occur … so that equipment problems can be identified, diagnosed and solved before a failure actually occurs.” (Sect. 2.4)"

column1: Scrap / Waste Ratio,Amount of scrap generated (and to be remelted) is given as a concrete efficiency KPI for steel production.,"“…from a globally required amount 1040 million tons of steel products, 334 million tons were discarded as waste…” (Sect. 4.2)"

Surface Quality Defects,Number and types of surface defects detected by optical sensors are used for quality performance tracking.,“…two optical surface test sensors … can continuously provide real-time data for the detection of surface defects…” (Sect. 4.4)

Efficiency of Business Processes,Efficiency (output per input) is referenced as an objective impacted by event patterns.,“…indicate important situations with a decisive impact on the efficiency of business processes.” (Sect. 2.2)

QoS (Quality of Service),Conjunto geral de atributos de desempenho usados para caracterizar e gerir SBAs.,"“Quality of Service (QoS) attributes – such as running time, resource consumption, or availability – are crucial for the practical usability and economic interest of service-based applications (SBAs).”  "
Running time,Atributo de QoS usado para avaliar a rapidez de execução de um serviço.,"“…such as running time, resource consumption, or availability…”  "
Resource consumption,"Atributo de QoS que mede recursos (CPU, memória, etc.) utilizados por um serviço.","“…such as running time, resource consumption, or availability…”  "
Availability,Atributo de QoS que mede o tempo em que um serviço fica acessível.,"“…such as running time, resource consumption, or availability…”  "

Response time,Métrica operacional monitorada em SBAs para adaptação e garantia de QoS.,"“The QoS characteristics we employed, like response time, price, shipment time, average order duration, etc.”  "
Price,Métrica econômica usada na comparação/seleção de serviços.,"“The QoS characteristics we employed, like response time, price, shipment time, average order duration, etc.”  "

Shipment time,"Tempo de entrega, usado como métrica de desempenho logístico em processos de negócio.","“The QoS characteristics we employed, like response time, price, shipment time, average order duration, etc.”  "
Average order duration,"Duração média de um pedido, usada como KPI de processos.","“The QoS characteristics we employed, like response time, price, shipment time, average order duration, etc.”  "

Data size (tamanho dos dados de entrada),Usado para prever variações de QoS e guiar adaptações sensíveis a dados.,"“The behaviour of a service … can significantly vary with the size and the content of its input data, leading to different QoS values.”  "
KPI (Key Performance Indicator),Indicador composto monitorado para disparar adaptações quando ocorre violação.,“…prediction of Key Performance Indicator (KPI) violations…”

KEI (Key Ecological Indicator),Indicador ecológico composto derivado de métricas de QoS para avaliar impacto ambiental.,"“so-called Key Ecological Indicators (KEI) , which are composite characteristics on the business process level, based on QoS…”  "
Greenness,Atributo emergente de qualidade usado em adaptações voltadas à sustentabilidade.,"“…quality attributes with emerging importance, such as greenness, trustworthiness, risk, value, etc.”  "
Trustworthiness,Atributo emergente usado para avaliar confiabilidade de um serviço.,"“…quality attributes with emerging importance, such as greenness, trustworthiness, risk, value, etc.”  "
Risk,Indicador de risco usado como atributo de decisão/adaptação e como KPI específico.,"“…greenness, trustworthiness, risk, value, etc.” / “…KPIs for trust, security, risk, sustainability…”  "
Value,Métrica de valor de negócio considerada em composições e adaptações.,"“…quality attributes with emerging importance, such as greenness, trustworthiness, risk, value, etc.”  "
Trust,"Indicador relacionado à confiança nos serviços, tratado como KPI em adaptações.","“…KPIs for trust, security, risk, sustainability and others.”  "
Security,Atributo/KPI de segurança monitorado para garantir qualidade e conformidade.,"“…KPIs for trust, security, risk, sustainability and others.”  "
Sustainability,KPI ligado à sustentabilidade ambiental/negocial considerado em futuras pesquisas.,"“…KPIs for trust, security, risk, sustainability and others.”"

medidor,uso_no_texto,evidencia_no_texto

Balanced Scorecard (BSC),Apresentado como exemplo de PMS que depende exclusivamente de indicadores numéricos (KPIs).,"“Balanced Scorecard (BSC) by Kaplan and Norton (1996)… are, sorted by their relevance and distribution in practice and literature”"
Performance Prism,Listado como PMS baseado em medidas quantitativas.,“Performance Prism by Neely et al. (2002)… rely on measures or KPIs”
SMART / Performance Pyramid,Outro PMS citado que utiliza apenas indicadores numéricos.,“SMART/Performance Pyramid by Lynch and Cross (1991)… rely on measures or KPIs”
Results/Determinants Matrix,Modelo mencionado entre os PMS dominados por KPIs.,“Results/Determinants Matrix by Fitzgerald and Moon (1996)… rely on measures or KPIs”
Performance Management Questionnaire,Exemplo de PMS quantitativo.,“Performance Management Questionnaire by Dixon et al. (1990)… rely on measures or KPIs”

Supportive Performance Measures / Performance Measurement Matrix,PMS incluído na lista dos que usam apenas indicadores numéricos.,“Supportive Performance Measures/Performance Measurement Matrix by Keegan et al. (1989)… rely on measures or KPIs”
Sink and Tuttle Model,Apresentado como PMS tradicional focado em métricas numéricas.,“Sink and Tuttle Model by Sink and Tuttle (1989)… rely on measures or KPIs”
Dynamic Performance Measurement System,Citada como PMS adicional com ênfase em métricas quantitativas.,“Dynamic Performance Measurement System by Latintnen (1996)”
Skandia’s Intellectual Capital Navigator,Modelo mencionado entre PMS baseados em indicadores numéricos.,“Skandia's Intellectual Capital Navigator by Edvinsson (1997)”
Integrated Dynamic Performance Measurement System,Listada como PMS que usa KPIs.,“Integrated Dynamic Performance Measurement system by Ghalayini et al. (1997)”
CMMI (Capability Maturity Model Integration),"Apresentado como PMS mais recente, também focado em medições estruturadas.",“CMMI by Kneuper (2003)… in this context discussed”
Integrated Performance Measurement System,Outro PMS centrado em indicadores numéricos.,“Integrated Performance Measurement System by Bititci et al. (1997)”
Ambite Performance Measurement Cube,Exemplo adicional de PMS quantitativo.,“Ambite Performance Measurement Cube by Bradley (1996)”
Integrated Performance Measurement Framework,Framework citado que depende de métricas numéricas.,“Integrated Performance Measurement Framework by Rouse and Putteril (2003)”
Intangible Success Factors,Introduzido como PMS porém ainda tratado como conjunto de indicadores medidos.,"“Intangible Success Factors, introduced by Lönnqvist (2004)”"
Brown’s Process-oriented Framework,Mencionado entre PMS baseados em KPIs.,"“Brown’s Process-oriented Framework, introduced by Brown (1996)”"
Organizational Performance Measurement,Modelo citado usando indicadores quantitativos.,"“the Organizational Performance Measurement, introduced by Chennell et al. (2000)”"

Key Performance Indicators (KPIs),Definidos como a forma numérica dominante de mensurar desempenho de processos.,“Numeric Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) evaluate business processes and allow the tactical management of an enterprise…”
Parâmetros numéricos (KPIs),Reforça a dominância de medidas quantitativas dentro dos PMS.,“…common performance measurement systems (PMS) that normally use numeric parameters (KPIs)…”

Medidor,Uso no texto,Evidência no texto

Balanced Scorecard (BSC),Sistema multidimensional de medição de desempenho usado para avaliar a saúde da empresa e originar boa parte da discussão atual sobre PMS.,"""There is consensus that the discussion about performance measurement fully emerged in practice and the academic literature in the early 1990s by the introduction of the Balanced Scorecard of Kaplan and Norton in 1992.""  "
Key Performance Indicators (KPIs),"Conjunto de indicadores quantitativos adoptado nos PMS
column2: o texto discute problemas de categorização, excesso de métricas e falta de ligação à estratégia.","""Problem: Categorization of KPIs … Motivation: Competitive pressures are forcing the industry to re-examine and improve its modus operandi [31]"" / ""Too many measures [39]""

column1: Six Sigma Metrics,Indicadores de defeitos/variabilidade usados em projetos Six Sigma para monitorar seu sucesso e a melhoria contínua.""","Referências a Six Sigma em [4] “Role of explicit and tacit knowledge in Six Sigma projects” e [8] “Selection of Six Sigma projects in the UK”, que tratam do uso de métricas para seleção e avaliação de projetos.  "

Medidas Não-Financeiras,Métricas intangíveis usadas para captar fatores de desempenho futuros que não aparecem nas demonstrações financeiras tradicionais.,"""Ittner, C. and Larcker, D., 'Coming Up Short on Nonfinancial Performance Measurement'""  "
Time-Based Management Measures,Uso de tempo/ciclo como métrica principal de competitividade e desempenho operacional.,"""Stalk, G., 'How Time-based Management Measures Performance'""  "
Métricas Lean,Indicadores associados à produção enxuta que avaliam eliminação de desperdícios e fluxo de valor.,"""Shah, R. and Ward, P., 'Defining and developing measures of lean production'""  "

Performance Prism,Scorecard orientado a stakeholders que mede e gere relações de valor além das finanças.,"""Neely, A., Adams, C. and Kennerley, M., The Performance Prism: The Scorecard for Measuring and Managing Stakeholder Relationship""  "

Modelo de Maturidade (PMS Maturity Model),Níveis de maturidade funcionam como medida do desenvolvimento e eficácia de sistemas de medição de desempenho.,"""Wettstein, T. and Kueng, P., 'A Maturity Model for Performance Measurement Systems'""  "

Visibilidade,Índice/constructo que mede o grau de compreensão e disponibilidade da informação de desempenho para redução de incerteza.,"""This degree of comprehension … has been introduced as visibility [35], [36], [95].""  "

Modelo Causal de Negócio,"Modelo que liga ‘value drivers’ à estratégia, permitindo derivar métricas causais de desempenho.","""Problem: To develop a causal business model describing how value drivers are linked to strategy … [66]"""
Pflug and Rinderle-Ma 2013 - Dynamic instance queuing in process-aware information systems.pdf
Metric,How it is used in the paper,Evidence excerpt (verbatim or almost-verbatim)

Processing time,Main performance target to be reduced at critical activities and overall.,“The core idea is that similar instances in a row can be processed faster … and are then distributed to dynamic queues accordingly. … offers the potential to reduce the processing time at critical activities.”

Estimated average processing time  E(B),Variable in the performance index used by the state-management to decide how many resources to activate.,"Formula 1:  pi(o)= (β * E(B) * n_i) + (γ * C_o,t * o * E(B))"
Waiting time,Part of the total sojourn/throughput time
column2: reduced when the queue is optimised.,"“46,1 seconds are allotted to waiting time, i.e. the interval between triggering a print job and the arrival at the printer.”"

column1: Sojourn time,Global time an instance spends in the system
column2: related to Little’s theorem and used in evaluation.,"“The average sojourn time is 149,9 seconds.”   /   “Little's theorem [15] allows a relation between the long-term average number of instances, the arrival rate, and the average sojourn time.”"

column1: Throughput time,End-to-end time of an instance
column2: equals processing time when no queue arises
column3: reduced by the approach.,"“No waiting times arise, the throughput time and processing time are the same.”"

column1: Average arrival time,Input parameter in classical queuing theory
column2: part of the motivation why static optimisation is hard.,“Most important parameters of any model are the average arrival times and processing times …”

column1: Arrival rate (λ),Parameter of Little’s theorem linking queue length and sojourn time.,"“Little's theorem … allows a relation between the long-term average number of instances, the arrival rate, and the average sojourn time.”"
Long-term average number of instances (L),One of the three variables in Little’s theorem mentioned to justify queue optimisation.,Same quote as above.
Capacity,Resource limit that causes queues
column2: implicitly optimised by changing number of active resources.,“If a resource does not have the capacity to handle all instances in time.”

column1: Number of resources (o),Decision variable of the state-management component
column2: varied each iteration.,“pi(o)… represents the trade-off between time and costs… multiplies with the number of resources o …”

column1: Cost per resource per time unit  C_o,t,Cost component in the performance index to balance speed vs. cost.,"Formula 1 and surrounding explanation: “C_o,t are the costs per resource and time unit.”"

Performance index  pi(o),Composite metric used at runtime to pick the best number of resources.,"Section 3.3: “We base the selection on a scalable performance index (formula 1)… In this decision function, lower values represent a better performance.”"
β (time weight),Weighting factor in pi(o) that expresses importance of time.,“β represents an individual factor for the importance of the time … remember that β + γ = 1.”
γ (cost weight),Weighting factor in pi(o) that expresses importance of cost.,Same sentence as above.
Changeover time,Preparatory time when a printer (or other resource) switches configuration
column2: reduced by clustering similar jobs.,"“Preparation times such as changeover procedures between color or slide modes take an estimated time of 5,0 seconds.” / “The average changeover time declines by 14 %.”"

column1: Preparation time,Synonym/part of changeover time
column2: contributes to total processing time.,"Figure 4 caption: “Preparation begins… 5,0 s”."

column1: Printing time,Immutable part of the process used to separate optimisable vs. fixed time.,"“The rest of the sojourn time is considered to be the ‘actual’ printing time.""
Cumulative changeover time""",Aggregate metric plotted to show total savings across the day.,Figure 6 title: “Cumulative changeover time in seconds” – comparison of FIFO vs. Dynamic Instance Queuing.
Queue length / Number of instances in system,Used to show how queues build up over time and to detect peaks.,Figure 5: “Number of instances in system” plotted against time.
Time savings,Derived metric (difference between two cumulative or average times) used to quantify improvement.,“Dynamic instance queuing achieves a saving from around nine minutes …”
Flexibility,Qualitative performance criterion
column2: claimed to improve because no design-time rules needed.,“Flexibility is an asset of dynamic instance queuing.”

column1: Quality of service,Additional performance criterion considered in the trade-off discussion.,"“The decision on the number of resources is a trade-off between time, costs, flexibility and quality of service.”"

Satisfaction / Customer satisfaction,Potential future optimisation metric suggested for the extended performance index.,“… further factors such as satisfaction can be taken into consideration as well.”
Idle time,Period with no work
column2: indirectly measured/optimised when resources are powered down.,"“…switches between three states (no printer active, one printer active, parallel activation of both printers).”"

column1: Energy / supply costs,Specific cost component saved when fewer printers are active.,"“Compared to the existing approach … dynamic state management offers savings … lower costs (energy, supplies) and less attrition.”"
Liu et al. 2018 - MLbench - benchmarking machine learning services against human experts.pdf
Metric,Como é usado no texto,Evidência literal extraída do artigo
Absolute Accuracy,Medir diretamente o desempenho de um sistema num dataset (“baseline absoluto”).,“Run a standard dataset … and report the absolute accuracy”
Relative Accuracy,Diferença de desempenho entre o serviço avaliado e um sistema de referência.,"“…and report the difference (i.e., relative accuracy) between it and Azure Machine Learning Studio.”  "

Ranking (posição ou % no leaderboard),Usado como métrica normalizada para comparar serviços e modelos entre diferentes competições.,“…being ranked among the top ξ %…” e “…we treat the top ten on the private leader board as ‘winning code’…”
Quality Tolerance (ξ),Percentual máximo de colocação no leaderboard aceitável para o utilizador
column2: base para as demais métricas.,“The quality tolerance of a user is ξ if s/he can be satisfied only by being ranked among the top ξ %...”

column1: Capacity c(M
column2: T),Menor quality-tolerance que um modelo/serviço atinge numa competição dada.,"“capacity, the minimum quality tolerance ξmin that M can meet for a given Kaggle competition T”  "

column1: Universality u(M
column2: ξ),Número de competições em que o modelo/serviço atinge uma dada quality-tolerance.,"“universality, the number of Kaggle competitions that M can achieve a quality tolerance of ξ.”  "

column1: Kryvinska 2012 - Building consistent formal specification for the service enterprise agility foundation.pdf
Medidor de performance,Como é usado no texto,Evidência no texto (trecho citado)
Key Performance Indicator (KPI),Indicador estratégico que liga objetivos de negócio aos processos e políticas
column2: base para medir desempenho corporativo,“The enterprise performance management layer focuses on specifying the strategic key performance indicators of the enterprise and tying these to underlying business processes…”

column1: Return on Investment (ROI),Modelo-base para avaliar benefícios e payback de investimentos em TI/Serviços e sustentar decisões de aprovação de projetos,"“Traditionally, this has taken the form of a return on investment (ROI) model … Demonstrating a positive ROI is the key factor in getting IT projects approved.”  "
Activity-Based Costing (ABC),Metodologia de custeio usada como métrica de performance financeira dentro de EPM,“Activity-Based Costing (ABC)” (lista de metodologias de EPM)
Shareholder Value Add (SVA),Mede valor adicionado ao acionista
column2: citado como métrica de EPM,"“Shareholder Value Add (SVA), also known as Economic Value Add (EVA)”  "

column1: Economic Value Add (EVA),Derivado do SVA
column2: mede criação de valor econômico,idem ao SVA: “also known as Economic Value Add (EVA)”

column1: Balanced Scorecard (BSC),Quadro de indicadores balanceados para ligar métricas a estratégia,“Balanced Scorecard (BSC)” (lista de metodologias)
Six Sigma,Métrica/metodologia de qualidade e produtividade usada para performance,“Six Sigma and Total Quality Management (TQM)”
Total Quality Management (TQM),Metodologia de gestão da qualidade usada como métrica de performance,idem linha anterior
Tempo de conclusão de processos,Mede eficiência operacional ao verificar processos não concluídos no prazo,Table 1: “not completing processes on time”
Produtividade de empregados / tempo para trabalho de valor agregado,Mede eficiência do trabalho humano e desperdício de horas,Table 1: “loss of employee productivity/time for value-add work”
Oportunidades de receita perdidas,Mede impacto financeiro de processos ineficientes,Table 1: “lost revenue opportunities/opportunity costs”
Custo de oportunidade,Valor econômico perdido por não agir
column2: usado para justificar ação rápida,Table 1: “opportunity costs”

column1: Desperdício de recursos humanos,Avalia uso ineficiente da força de trabalho,Table 1: “waste of precious human resources”
Perda de negócio existente,Indicador de impacto negativo em receitas atuais,Table 1: “loss of existing business” (vários itens)
Perda de novas oportunidades de negócio,Mede incapacidade de capturar receitas futuras,Table 1: “loss of new business opportunities”
Falha em acompanhar concorrentes,Indicador de competitividade/agilidade,Table 1: “failure to keep pace with competitors”
Custo de correção de erros,Mede gastos adicionais causados por erros operacionais,Table 1: “costs to fix errors”
Impacto negativo na reputação,Métrica intangível de valor de marca e confiança,Table 1: “negative impact on reputation”
Penalidades regulatórias,Custos de compliance por não conformidade,Table 1: “penalties from management and government or regulatory agencies”
Perda de certificação,Indicador de compliance e qualidade,Table 1: “loss of certification”
Danos à reputação,Outro indicador de impacto intangível de compliance,Table 1: “damage to reputation”
Perda de impacto econômico,Indicador de resultado financeiro agregado de falhas de compliance,Table 1: “loss of economic impact”
Eficácia/ineficiência de processos,Mede capacidade de otimização de processos e eliminação de gargalos,Table 1: “inefficient processes – inability to optimize processes”
Yanine and Campos 2023 - Sustaining Business Performance Management - An Operational Framework.pdf
Performance Measure,Description/Usage in Text,Evidence from Text

Balanced Scorecard (BSC),Classical multi-perspective performance measurement system used as reference for business performance management (BPM) in the paper.,"“…performance dimensions and metrics of the traditional Balanced Scorecard model (Kaplan and Norton, 2001)…”  "
Financial Perspective (KPI set of the BSC),Measures economic/financial results
column2: cited as the dimension most commonly used by SMEs.,“…business performance indicators being used are linked to economic and financial benchmarks…”

column1: Customer/Community Perspective (BSC),Measures value delivered to customers and local community
column2: stressed in the proposed framework.,“Customer and community perspective” (Figure 1).

column1: Learning & Growth Perspective (BSC),"Measures people, culture and innovation capabilities
column2: appears in the operational framework.",“Learning and growth perspective” (Figure 1).

column1: Internal-Process Perspective (BSC),Implied as a core BSC dimension driving operations efficiency and sustainability.,Figure 1 shows four prevalent perspectives that characterise and support enterprise sustainability.
SMD3D – Sustainable Dimension,Part of the three-dimensional strategic PMS for wineries
column2: measures how sustainable the business is.,"“…a three-dimensional strategic performance measurement system (SMD3D) encompassing three key dimensions: sustainable, temporal, and spatial.”  "

column1: SMD3D – Temporal Dimension,Links long-term strategy with day-to-day activity in wineries.,“…linking the measurement of strategic performance with the day-to-day activity…”
SMD3D – Spatial Dimension,Adds geographical/location view to performance assessment in wineries.,"“…three key dimensions: sustainable, temporal, and spatial.”  "
Water Consumption,Quantified use of water that firms must report
column2: indicator of environmental performance.,“companies must report water consumption to government authorities…”

column1: Waste Generation/Reduction,Amount of waste and efforts to cut it
column2: tied to efficiency and material cost KPIs.,"“…focus on reducing waste which could, in turn, improve process efficiency, and reduce the amount … of materials used.”  "

column1: Process Efficiency,Derived KPI linked to waste and resource use improvements.,same sentence as above — “…improve process efficiency…”
Material Use/Material Cost,Indicator derived from waste reduction and efficiency initiatives.,“…reduce the amount (and therefore the cost) of materials used.”
Energy Consumption,Tracking absolute energy use in operations.,"Table 1 row: “Energy Conservation, efficiency + use of renewables”  "
Energy Efficiency,Ratio or saving derived from energy initiatives.,"same table row: “Energy Conservation, efficiency + use of renewables”  "
Renewable-Energy Share,Portion of energy from renewable sources
column2: part of sustainability policies.,same table row as above.

column1: Carbon Emissions,Absolute/relative GHG emissions to be cut by firms.,Table 1 row: “Cut Carbon Emissions and Register C footprint”
Carbon Footprint Registration,Formal metric/report of carbon output.,same table row as above.
Community Involvement Index,Measures extent/quality of firm’s engagement with local community.,Table 1 rows: “Community involvement & empathy”
column2: “Focus on helping the needy and reach out to community”

column1: Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) Practices,Aggregate indicator of environmental & social practices adopted by SMEs.,“…implementation of corporate social responsibility (CSR) and environmental management practices in SMEs as competitive traits…”
Environmental Management (EM) Practices,Score or count of EM tools used by the firm.,same sentence as above.

Motivation/Pressures/Targets/Methods for EM-CSR,Survey-based indicators explaining why and how SMEs adopt EM/CSR.,"“…study reveal SMEs' motivation, pressures, targets and methods for adopting environmental management (EM) and CSR practices…”  "
Number of Employees,Firm-size attribute used as explanatory variable for sustainability actions.,"“…vary considerably with respect to size, turnover rate and geographical locations.”  "
Turnover Rate (Sales),Financial size/sales volume used to analyse sustainability adoption.,same sentence as above.
Geographical Location,Spatial variable affecting sustainability practices
column2: also part of SMD3D.,same sentence as above
column3: and SMD3D spatial dimension.

column1: Financial Performance,Outcome metric expected to improve through sustainable practices.,"“…companies have started to focus on the environment, people, and the planet with the belief that it will lead to better financial performance.”  "
Profitability,Specific financial result linked to sustainability actions.,“…sustainability actions of SMEs—rather than being profitability-driven—can be understood…”
Innovation-Led Revenue Generation,Revenue growth derived from sustainability-oriented innovation.,“…innovation-led revenue generation and overall competitive advantage.”

Compliance-Led Risk Mitigation,KPI capturing reduction in regulatory/operational risk through ES initiatives.,"“…compliance-led risk mitigation, efficiency-led cost reductions, innovation-led revenue generation…”"

Cost / Costs,"BPM/PO reduces different types of cost (general costs, inventory costs).",“extraordinary improvements in cost” (Hammer)
column2: “reduction of costs” (Schmelzer & Sesselmann)
column3: “lower inventory costs” (Volvo case).

column3: “improvement of product quality” (results section).

column1: Service Quality,Better quality of the services offered.,“improvement of … service quality” (Hinterhuber).

column2: “improvement of process quality, e.g. the errors within the process are minimized” (results section)."

column2: “lower cycle times” (Schmelzer & Sesselmann)
column3: “shortened lead-times” (Volvo case)
column4: “faster throughput times” (results)
column5: “process speed improvements” (results).

column1: Profitability / Profits,Higher profitability is reported as an outcome of BPM.,“extraordinary improvements in … profitability” (Hammer)
column2: “higher profits” (Schmelzer & Sesselmann).

column1: Financial Performance (aggregate),Overall financial results improve.,“banks … also tend to have a better financial performance” (Frei et al.)
column2: “improvement of financial performance” (results).

column1: Sales,BPM contributes to increased sales levels.,“increase of sales” (Schmelzer & Sesselmann).
Company Value,Long-term enterprise value rises.,“higher company value” (Schmelzer & Sesselmann).
Customer Satisfaction,Greater satisfaction reported by customers.,“higher customer satisfaction” (Schmelzer & Sesselmann)
column2: “direct impact … on customer satisfaction” (Gustafsson et al.)
column3: “higher customer satisfaction” (results).

column1: Customer Orientation,Processes become more aligned to customer needs.,“PO leads to a better customer orientation” (results).
Productivity / Efficiency,Resources are used more efficiently
column2: productivity grows.,“improvement of … productivity” (Hinterhuber)
column3: “gained efficiency/productivity” (results).

column1: Growth,BPM acts as an enabler of organisational growth.,“PO leads to growth or acts as an enabler for growth” (results).
Delivery Reliability / On-time Delivery / Ability to Deliver,Higher reliability in meeting promised delivery dates.,“increased delivery reliability” (Volvo case)

column3: “improve the ability to deliver” (results).

column1: Inventory Cost,A derivative cost measure—cost tied up in inventory is reduced.,“lower inventory costs” (Volvo case).

Flexibility,Ability to adapt quickly to environmental changes increases.,“PO led to higher flexibility in terms of being able to rapidly adapt the organization to changing environmental conditions” (results).
Employee Motivation / Satisfaction,Positive impact on human-resource related outcomes.,“higher employee motivation and satisfaction” (results).
Communication,Better internal communication is perceived.,“PO facilitates communication within the organization” (results).

column1: Liu et al. 2013 - Selecting checkpoints along the time line - a novel te ... ection strategy for monitoring a batch of parallel business processes.pdf
Medidor de Performance,Como é usado no texto,Evidência no texto
Número de checkpoints selecionados,Serve como indicador directo do custo de monitoramento e de tratamento de violações
column2: é comparado entre TD CSS (activity-point) e TP CSS (time-point).,"“…the total number of checkpoints will be enormous…”, “…the number of checkpoints selected by TD CSS… is much higher than the number of throughput checkpoints selected by TP CSS…”, Tabela 1."

column1: Taxa de redução de checkpoints,Mede o ganho obtido pela nova estratégia
column2: calculada como a percentagem de diminuição do número total de checkpoints.,“The reduction rate of the checkpoints ranges from 98 % to 78 % with an average of 87 %.”

column1: Throughput em tempo de execução (THS_t),Indicador principal proposto
column2: mede quantas actividades são concluídas por unidade de tempo e é verificado em cada ponto de verificação de throughput.,Definição 1: “…the current system throughput is defined as …”

column1: Throughput médio esperado,Usado como referência para decidir se o ponto de tempo corrente vira checkpoint (se o throughput real < throughput médio).,"Estratégia TP CSS: “At a system time point S_p, if TH_runtime > TH_mean … then S_p is selected as a throughput checkpoint…”"
Número de violações de throughput,Conta quantas vezes o sistema ficou inconsistente em termos de throughput
column2: usado para accionar o SERP.,"Tabela 1 – coluna ‘throughput violations’, “…the number of throughput violations for the parallel processes.”"

column1: Taxa de violação de throughput,Percentual de checkpoints de throughput em que se detectou violação
column2: reflete desempenho global da estratégia.,Figura 2 mostra a evolução das violações quando TP CSS é aplicado.

column1: Número de violações de tempo de resposta,Indica quantas actividades individuais excederam os limites
column2: parâmetro de comparação com violações de throughput.,“…the total number of response time violations for individual processes…” (Tabela 1).

column1: Taxa de violação global,"Percentual de processos que falham em cumprir o prazo final
column2: apresentada para NIL, TD CSS + SERP e TP CSS + SERP.",“Figure 2 depicts the global violation rates (the unsuccessful rate for meeting the final deadline).”

column1: Taxa de conclusão no prazo (on-time completion rate),Métrica alvo do sistema
column2: pretende-se mantê-la ≥ 90 %.,"“…while maintaining satisfactory on-time completion rates…”, “…denotes the probability of 90 % for on-time completion…”"

column1: Custo de monitoramento,"Associado directamente ao número de checkpoints
column2: quanto mais checkpoints, maior o custo.","“…the larger the number of selected checkpoints, the higher the monitoring cost…”"

column1: Custo de tratamento de violações,Cresce com o número de checkpoints e com a quantidade de violações detectadas
column2: reduzido ao concentrar checkpoints por tempo.,“…the monitoring cost and violation handling cost [are] very small… an order of magnitude reduction…”

column1: Overhead de execução da estratégia,Tempo/recursos gastos em consultas e computação para decidir checkpoints
column2: declarado como baixo.,“The overhead for our strategy… is very small. It is very close to the overhead for the conventional activity-point based strategy…”

column1: Duração em tempo de execução de uma actividade R(a_i),Variável usada para calcular throughput e detectar violações de tempo de resposta.,Definição 1: “…with its runtime (i.e. real) duration denoted as R(a_i)…”.

Duração média de uma actividade M(a_i),Serve de referência para avaliar atrasos individuais e para o cálculo do throughput médio esperável.,Definição 1: “…mean (i.e. expected) duration denoted as M(a_i)…”.
Duração em tempo de execução de um processo R(P_i),Usada na verificação de consistência do throughput em checkpoints.,Definição 3 usa “…ma_R…” somando durações de actividades restantes.
Duração média de um processo M(P_i),Usada no modelo de consistência de throughput como valor esperado.,Definição 3 inclui “…ma_M…”.
Percentil normal (1.28),Derivado que estabelece o prazo global de 90 % de confiança
column2: determina o deadline usado nos testes.,“…we specify the normal percentiles as 1.28 which denotes the probability of 90 % for on-time completion…”

column1: Razão de ruído (noise ratio),Percentual de atraso artificial aplicado à duração de actividades para simular incertezas
column2: afecta directamente os indicadores de desempenho.,“…Different ratio of noises … from 5 % to 30 % are implemented.”

indicador,como_e_usado_no_texto,evidencia_no_texto

Number of rejected components,"Exemplo de indicador do tipo Counter, cujo valor pode ser incrementado ou decrementado para medir qualidade/eficiência do processo.","“Counter : a value that may be increased or decreased (e.g., number of rejected components).”"

Working capital,"Exemplo de indicador do tipo Difference, calculado como diferença entre dois valores financeiros.","“Difference : a value that results from the difference of two other values (e.g., working capital).”"

Average of rejected orders weekly,"Exemplo de indicador do tipo Average, obtido pela média semanal de pedidos rejeitados.","“Average : a value that represents an average over a certain period (e.g., average of rejected orders weekly).”"

Rejection ratio daily,"Exemplo de indicador do tipo Partition, representando a razão entre partes (pedidos rejeitados) e o todo por dia.","“Partition : a value that represents the ratio of a part to the totality (e.g., rejection ratio daily).”"

Labor cost index,"Exemplo de indicador do tipo Indexes, calculado como razão de dois valores, utilizado para séries estatísticas.","“Indexes : a value that results from the ratio of two values, typically used to explain statistical series (e.g., labor cost index).”"

Return on equity,"Exemplo de indicador do tipo Correlation (relative), razão entre dois valores numéricos de conceitos diferentes.","“Correlation  (relative): a value representing the ratio of two numerical values of different concepts (e.g., return on equity).”"

Ratio Final Orders Daily (RFd),Valores diários de razão de pedidos finalizados
column2: insumo para o cálculo de RFw.,Figura 1: “ratio final orders (daily)… RFd0 RFd1 … RFd6”

column2: os modelos de performance são compostos por KPIs que recebem valores, são monitorados e propagam impacto para as metas GRL.","“…extends the URN notation with Key Performance Indicators (KPI) and other concepts to measure, and align processes and goals.”  "

column1: Evaluation Value,Valor real obtido em tempo de execução (ou teste) que é comparado com Target/Threshold/Worst.,“…Evaluation Value is the KPI’s actual value retrieved from back-end business data sources at run-time or defined by users for test purposes at design time.”
Evaluation Level,Nível resultante (-100 a 100) utilizado pelo algoritmo GRL após mapear Evaluation Value.,Figura 7 mostra o mapeamento das quatro faixas “…>100 … <-100” aos níveis GRL.

Objective Key Results (OKR),Used by Lisy to translate strategic goals into individual targets and to track employee progress
column2: reviewed every semester during PD&D sessions.,"“Every Lisy employee has their own targets that must be achieved in a certain measure. Objective key results (OKRs) measure progress towards achieving these targets… everyone has an OKR, which will be assessed every semester through the performance development and discussion (PD&D) agenda.”"

column1: Key Performance Indicator (KPI),"1) In Rise, KPIs are the main basis for the yearly appraisal of every member. 2) Operational KPIs are also tied to shipper-defined service levels.",“Employee performance measurement carried out by Rise is by measuring the achievement of KPIs from each member each year.”
column2: axial-coding note: “KPI from shipper SLA”.

column1: Performance Plan Index (PPI) / Index Performance Plan (IPP),Document created at the start of the year that specifies the KPIs each employee commits to achieve.,“This assessment refers to the performance plan index (PPI) prepared at the beginning of the year from discussions between employees and their leaders at the head level.”
Index Performance Review (IPR),Year-end evaluation that compares actual results with the previously agreed Performance Plan Index.,“This plan is then assessed through an index performance review.”

Net Promoter Score (NPS),Metric used by Lisy to determine if customer problems have been solved and to gauge overall customer satisfaction.,"“Through this pillar, Lisy can assess whether customer problems have been resolved with the services provided. One measure is using a net promoter score (NPS).”"
Service Level Agreement (SLA) metrics,Operational performance targets set by shippers that Lisy must meet and monitor as part of its KPIs.,Axial-coding table entry: “KPI from shipper SLA”.

column1: Lehnert et al. 2016 - Value-based process project portfolio management - integrated planning of BPM capability development and process improvement.pdf
Medidor,Uso no texto,Evidência no texto
Tempo,"Dimensão de desempenho de processos (usada para avaliar, comparar e melhorar processos
column2: afeta número de instâncias, ciclo de vida, etc.)","“process performance indicators are often grouped according to the Devil’s Quadrangle, a multi-dimensional framework that comprises time, cost, quality, and flexibility as performance dimensions (Reijers and Mansar 2005).”"

column1: Custo,"Dimensão de desempenho de processos
column2: inclui desembolsos operacionais, fixos e de investimento.","mesma citação da Devil’s Quadrangle
column3: além de “operating outflows, fixed outflows, and investment outflows”"

column1: Qualidade,"Dimensão de desempenho
column2: usada para medir defeitos, satisfação do cliente, limites críticos, efeito de degeneração.","mesma citação da Devil’s Quadrangle
column3: e “quality usually has an upper boundary (e.g., error rate)”"

column1: Flexibilidade,"Dimensão de desempenho incluída no Devil’s Quadrangle, considerada em trocas entre métricas.",mesma citação da Devil’s Quadrangle

Valor Presente Líquido (NPV),Métrica financeira central para avaliar a contribuição de valor de roteiros de projetos.,“the planning model’s objective function measures the value contribution of project roadmaps in terms of their NPV”
Valor Presente Líquido Esperado (ENPV),Usado para decisões sob risco com decisores neutros.,"“Under risk with risk-neutral decision-makers, decisions can be made based on the expected NPV.”"
NPV ajustado ao risco,Usado quando decisores são avessos a risco
column2: pode ser calculado via taxa de juro ajustada ao risco.,"“In case of risk-averse decision-makers, alternatives can be valued via their risk-adjusted expected NPV … calculated via … a risk-adjusted interest rate (Copeland et al. 2005).”"

column1: Contribuição de valor,Indicador agregado que o modelo maximiza
column2: deriva do NPV.,“determine the value contribution of different project roadmaps”

column1: Fluxo de caixa,Base para cálculo do NPV
column2: inclui entradas e saídas periódicas.,“The NPV integrates multiple periodic cash flows by discounting them back to the point of decision”

column1: Desembolsos de investimento,Saídas de caixa para execução de projetos em andamento.,“Investment outflows accrue for implementing currently running projects.”
Desembolsos operacionais,Saídas de caixa variáveis por instância de processo.,“operating outflows”
Desembolsos fixos do processo,Custos fixos específicos de cada processo em cada período.,“process-specific fixed outflows”

Desembolsos fixos de BPM,Custos fixos gerais relacionados a BPM que afetam vários processos.,"“Overarching fixed outflows capture BPM-related fixed outflows for multiple processes, such as operating a center of process excellence”"
Entradas operacionais,Receitas por instância executada (preço de venda ou transferência).,"“operating inflows (i.e., the sales price for core processes and the transfer price for support processes)”"
Número de instâncias,Volume de execuções de um processo por período
column2: influencia fluxo de caixa.,“the number of instances that a core process is executed reflects the process’ external customer demand”

column1: Preço por execução,Preço interno ou externo cobrado por execução de processo.,Definição na Eq. (2): “Iop_i is the internal or external price for executing process i once”
Tempo de ciclo,Exemplo de métrica de tempo impactada por projetos (reduzido em minutos).,"“reduces the average cycle time (e.g., by 25 %)”"
Satisfação do cliente,Exemplo de métrica de qualidade (pontos de satisfação) usada para medir efeitos de projeto.,"“increases quality in terms of customer satisfaction (e.g., by 10 points)”"
Taxa de erros,Exemplo de limite superior de qualidade (erro %).,"“quality usually has an upper boundary (e.g., error rate)”"
Nível de maturidade do processo,Medida de qualidade usada pelos especialistas para avaliar processos.,“Process quality was consistently measured in terms of maturity levels”
Grau percebido de mudança,Indicador utilizado por Forstner et al. para avaliar projetos.,tabela de comparação: “maximizes the weighted perceived degree of change”
Grau percebido de mudança ponderado,Versão ponderada do indicador anterior para priorização.,mesma evidência

Reputação,Dimensão de valor no Business Value Scoring (BVS).,"tabela de comparação: “The BVS … includes the six dimensions reputation, clients, business processes, financial opportunity, regulation and compliance, and human resources”"
Clientes,Dimensão BVS.,mesma evidência
Processos de negócio (dimensão)," ""Dimensão BVS.""",mesma evidência
Oportunidade financeira,Dimensão BVS.,mesma evidência
Regulação & compliance,Dimensão BVS.,mesma evidência
Recursos humanos,Dimensão BVS.,mesma evidência
Gap de serviço (SERVQUAL),Indicador de desempenho de serviço usado na seleção de processos.,tabela de comparação: “A perceived service gap is derived based on the SERVQUAL model”
Diferenciação do processo,Característica usada na categorização e priorização de processos.,"tabela de comparação: “processes in terms of differentiation, formality, and value network governance”"
Formalidade do processo,Característica usada na categorização de processos.,mesma evidência
Governança da rede de valor,Característica usada na categorização de processos.,mesma evidência
Risco,Variável considerada via taxa ajustada ou ENPV para avaliar projetos.,“Risk is considered using the risk-adjusted expected NPV.”

Robustez,Medida de sensibilidade do roteiro ótimo a variações de parâmetros.,“The robustness check calculates how strongly the value contribution of the optimal roadmap is affected by variations in the input parameters.”
Orçamento,Restrição periódica ou global usada como critério de seleção.,"descrição na Tabela 1: “Budget(x,y) In period y, there is a budget x”"
Número de projetos,Limite de projetos simultâneos que pode ser executado.,"Tabela 1: “NumProj(x,y) … the number of all currently running projects must not exceed x”"
Efeito de degeneração da qualidade (gᵢ),Parâmetro que reduz qualidade quando não há projetos de melhoria.,“gi … is the process-specific quality degeneration effect”
Efeito de degeneração do tempo (hᵢ),Parâmetro que aumenta tempo quando não há projetos.,“hi … is the process-specific time degeneration effect”
Limite máximo de qualidade (qmax),Fronteira superior que a qualidade não pode exceder.,Eq. (3): “qmax_i is the process-specific upper quality boundary”
Limite crítico de qualidade,"Restrição QualMin(x,i,y) que impede qualidade abaixo de x.","Tabela 1: “QualMin(x,i,y) There is a critical quality boundary x”"
Limite crítico de tempo,"Restrição TimeMax(x,i,y) que impede tempo acima de x.","Tabela 1: “TimeMax(x,i,y) There is a critical time boundary x”"
Lee et al. 2020 - A sequential search framework for selecting weights of dispatching rules in manufacturing systems.pdf
Performance_Measure,How_It_Is_Used_in_the_Text,Evidence_in_the_Text
Throughput,Core KPI to evaluate schedules
column2: compared between search methods
column3: focus on photo-lithography machines but also cited for the whole system.,"""…to improve the throughput and utilization of systems."" (Abstract) / ""We considered the setup times and throughput of the machines of the photo-lithography process as the key performance indicators (KPIs)…"" (Section 2)  "

column1: Utilization,Mentioned together with throughput as a global performance goal for the manufacturing system.,"""…in order to improve the throughput and utilization of the systems."" (Abstract)  "
Setup Times,Core KPI
column2: lower values desired
column3: summed over 3-day horizon and compared between methods.,"""…such as throughput or setup times…"" (Section 1) / ""We considered the setup times … as the KPI…"" (Section 2)  "

column1: Sum of Setup Times,Concrete aggregated metric reported in minutes for 3 days of production.,"""The average sum of setup times of three days of production with the proposed framework is 1911.74 minutes…"" (Section 4, Table 4 discussion)  "
Throughput of Machines,Specific throughput metric for photo-lithography machines
column2: measured in lots processed during 3 days.,"""The mean throughput of three days of production with the proposed framework is 373,082.7 lots…"" (Section 4, Table 5 discussion)  "

column1: Throughput of Photo-lithography Machines,Detailed throughput KPI repeatedly tabulated under different time limits (3 h and 8 h).,"""The throughput of photo-lithography machines with the 3 hour limit…"" (Table 5 title)  "
KPI (generic),Umbrella term for any performance indicator used in the study
column2: input to decision tree and search steps.,"""Collect KPIs for the schedules generated with the sampled weight sets…"" (Section 3.2)  "

column1: Mean KPI ( ȳ_j ),Average KPI value inside each decision-tree sub-space
column2: component of performance score P_j.,"""ȳ_j is the mean of the KPI… in sub-space j"" (Section 3.4)  "

column1: Best KPI ( y*_j ),Best KPI observed in each sub-space
column2: second component of performance score P_j.,"""y*_j are the mean of the KPI and the best KPI in sub-space j respectively…"" (Section 3.4)  "

column1: Composite Performance Score P_j,Weighted sum of mean and best KPI (α ȳ_j + β y*_j)
column2: used to allocate samples among sub-spaces.,"""P_j = α ȳ_j + β y*_j …"" (Equation 1, Section 3.4)  "

column1: Standard Deviation of KPI Values,Measure of variability of KPIs across replications
column2: reported for both setup times and throughput.,"""Standard deviation"" column in Tables 4, 5, 7  "

column1: Percentile Rank of KPI Values,Relative ranking of obtained KPIs among 450 random samples
column2: used to compare methods.,"""Table 6: Percentile rank of KPI values obtained from the proposed framework and random search among 450 randomly generated samples…"" (Section 4)"
