Relative Error (in user interactions),"Metric to quantify average deviation (start + end) between predicted and real boundaries, divided by number of instances","""As evaluation metrics we choose the relative error in user interactions, the classification correctness, and the percentage of recognized instances.  The relative error is the deviation of the predicted start and end points of the process instances to the actual start and end points divided by the number of instances to predict."""
Weinzierl et al. 2020 - Prescriptive business process monitoring for recommending next best actions.pdf
Performance_Metric,Usage_in_Text,Evidence_in_Text

Key Performance Indicator (KPI ‑ generic),Umbrella term for all performance measures considered when optimising or evaluating business processes.,“Organisations measure the performance of processes through key performance indicators (KPIs)…”
KPI – Time,Dimension of KPI concerned with duration-related goals.,"“…in regard to three dimensions: time, cost and quality [23].”"
KPI – Cost,Dimension of KPI concerned with monetary goals.,"“…in regard to three dimensions: time, cost and quality [23].”"
KPI – Quality,Dimension of KPI concerned with quality-related goals.,"“…in regard to three dimensions: time, cost and quality [23].”"
Throughput Time (KPI),Main KPI the authors optimise
column2: total duration of a process instance.,“…we evaluate optimisation of the KPI throughput time (in-time value)…”

column1: Total Process Time vs. Deadline,Example measure showing whether instance duration exceeds an agreed limit.,“…the complete process instance takes 6 hours and a deadline of 5 hours … is exceeded.”
Total Process Cost,Example KPI used in running example to select cheaper suffixes.,"“The values 20, 40 and 10 assigned to the events are KPI values (e.g. cost values) predicted by mpp.”"
In-Time Value,Derived metric: percentage of instances that meet the temporal threshold.,“…in-time value) by the percentage of process instances that could comply with the temporal threshold…”
Temporal Threshold,Benchmark value (average throughput time) used to judge if an instance is on time.,“The temporal threshold is the average throughput time of a process instance in an event log.”

Average Damerau-Levenshtein Distance,Similarity metric to measure distance between recommended and real trace.,“…distance from ground truth process instance through the average Damerau-Levenshtein distance.”
Categorical Cross-Entropy Loss,Learning performance measure for next activity classification.,“…categorical cross-entropy loss for next activity predictions…”
Mean Squared Error (MSE),Learning performance measure for numerical KPI (throughput time) prediction.,“…and a mean squared error for throughput time (KPI) predictions.”

Reliability Estimate,"Measure of confidence in predictions, used to influence interventions.",“Metzger et al. [11] investigate the effect of reliability estimates on (1) intervention costs … and (2) the rate of non-violation…”
Intervention/Adaption Cost,Cost metric representing effort of taking preventive action.,“…intervention costs (called adaption cost)… by performing a simulation of a parameterised cost model.”
Rate of Non-Violation,Proportion of cases that finish without violating constraints
column2: used as success metric.,“…and (2) the rate of non-violation of process instances…”

column1: Risk Metric,Probability/impact measure used for recommending actions that minimise risk.,“…predicts risks … to provide decision support for certain actions… which minimises process risks.”

Delay Occurrence (Binary Outcome),Binary performance indicator signalling whether a process instance is late.,“…additionally predict the binary process outcome whether a delay occurs in the process or not.”
Remaining Time,Predictive measure of how long a running case will still take.,“…prediction tasks like predicting … remaining time [4].”

Key Performance Indicator (KPI),Term-guarda-chuva usado como métrica principal para avaliar se a organização está alcançando seus objetivos de negócio
column2: é medido tanto na fase de diagnóstico (null measurement) quanto na fase de execução para fins de comparação.,“A Key Performance Indicators (KPI) is a metric which is used to determine how an organization is performing against its business objectives.”

column1: Internal KPI,"KPIs calculados a partir de recursos internos da organização (bases de dados, execution logs do BPMS) para medir desempenho durante a execução do processo.",“In the enactment phase we measure KPIs from the BPMS data like databases and execution logs. These KPI measured by the use of internal resources of the organization will be considered as internal KPI(s).”
External KPI,KPIs obtidos a partir de dados de redes sociais públicas
column2: servem para complementar e comparar com os indicadores internos.,“we will use the data collected from public SN to measure other KPI(s) which will be considered as external KPI.”

column1: Time of making an order,Exemplo concreto de KPI quantitativo usado para expressar o objetivo de satisfação do cliente.,"“A qualitative objective can be customer satisfaction, this can be expressed quantitatively through key performance indicators (KPIs) such as the time of making an order.”  "

column2: citado como motivador para medir desempenho do processo.,"“A qualitative objective can be customer satisfaction, this can be expressed quantitatively through key performance indicators (KPIs)...”"

column1: Lendermann et al. 2010 - Unlocking value from component exchange contracts in aviation using simulation-based optimisation.pdf
Metric,How it is used in the text,Evidence (exact citation or location reference)
On-time performance,Key high–level KPI for airline operations
column2: the whole study is motivated by the need to improve this metric.,"“On-time performance, based on the on-time departure of the aircraft, is considered as one of the key success factors of the airline industry.” (Section 1)  "

column1: Technical delay,Stated as the principal risk factor that jeopardises on-time performance.,“…the major risks associated with on-time departure is technical delay.” (Section 1)

Protection Level PLₙ,Traditional Airbus Initial Provisioning (IP) performance target: probability that no more than n units of a part are simultaneously in repair.,“Airbus … has traditionally been making IP recommendations for rotables to operators based on a Protection Level PLn which is defined as the probability of not having more than n spare units of a particular part number concurrently in the repair cycle.” (Section 2)
Expected demand during re-supply period (E),Intermediate measure to compute PLₙ
column2: represents the number of removals expected while previous units are in repair.,Formula given: “E = (FH × QPA × N × TAT)/(MTBUR × 365).” (Section 2)

column1: Service Level SLₙ,Primary contractual KPI in component-exchange agreements: proportion of demand instances fulfilled on time.,"“…component service providers typically commit to a Service Level SLn, defined as the number of demand instances that can be fulfilled in time divided by the total number of demand instances.” (Section 2)  "
Fill rate,Used interchangeably with Service Level when comparing PL and SL (Figure 1).,Caption of Figure 1: “Illustration Fill Rate versus Availability.” (Section 2)
No-fill event count,Operational metric: a demand that cannot be satisfied immediately
column2: used in cost and service-level calculations.,"“…a no-fill event can happen, which is at any time when all available spare part units are in the repair cycle.” (Section 2) and cost tables list “Expected value of no-fill events p.a.”  "

column1: Mean Time Between Unscheduled Removals (MTBUR),Reliability metric of a component
column2: appears in E-formula and tables
column3: also traded-off against cost in optimisation.,“…MTBUR: Mean time between unscheduled removals = Reliability of component.” (Section 2)

column1: Turn-Around Time (TAT),Part of E-formula
column2: longer TAT increases inventory need and drives rebalancing logic.,“TAT: Turnaround time = Duration of component repair (including logistics transfer time to/from repair).” (Section 2)

column1: Annual Flight Hours (FH),Input driver of demand
column2: appears in E-formula and pooling evaluation.,“FH: Annual flight hours per aircraft” (Section 2) and Table 1 summarises “# of inbound flights”.

column1: Quantity per Aircraft (QPA),Used to scale MTBUR and demand
column2: appears in formula and component tables
column3: derivative MTBUR/QPA used for ranking.,“QPA: Quantity per aircraft…” (Section 2) and Table 2 shows QPA and derived ‘MTBUR/QPA’.

column1: MTBUR/QPA,Derived reliability per installed position
column2: used to order components for cost arbitrage discussion.,“The part numbers in the output table are sequenced in the order of increasing MTBUR/QPA.” (Section 3)

column1: Service Level Achieved (simulated),Resulting KPI from each optimisation run
column2: must be ≥ 97 %.,Tables 3–9 column “Service Level Achieved” and text: “…subject to a minimum overall service level of 97%…” (Section 3)

column1: Confidence level for observing ≥ 97 % SL within 3 months,Risk metric ensuring short-term performance
column2: drives higher long-term SL.,"“Because the required confidence level to observe at least 97% service level is 90%, this can be achieved only with an inventory configuration corresponding to a long-term service level of 99.42%.” (Section 3)  "

column1: Expected value of total inventory cost p.a.,Cost performance measure
column2: part of optimisation objective.,Tables 3–9 row “Expected Value of Total Inventory Cost p.a.”

column1: Expected value of total logistics cost p.a.,Cost KPI accounting for urgent shipments and rebalancings.,Tables 3–9 row “Expected Value of Total Logistics Costs p.a.”
Expected value of total penalty cost p.a.,Cost for no-fill events
column2: included in objective function.,“…penalty cost (assumed to be $500 for each no-fill event)…” (Section 3) and tables list “Expected Value of Total Penalty Cost p.a.”

column1: Expected total lifecycle cost p.a.,Main economic performance metric (inventory + logistics + penalty)
column2: minimised in optimisation.,Tables 3–9 row “Expected Value of Total Service Lifecycle Cost …”

column1: Total inventory (units) / Pool stock,Physical KPI measuring number of spare units held
column2: compared across policies.,Tables 3–10 list “Total Pool Stock” or “Total inventory (units)”.

column1: Expected # of logistics movements p.a.,"Operational KPI for transport workload
column2: broken into Deliveries, Re-balancings, Replenishments.",Tables 3–9 row “Expected Value of # of Logistics Movements p.a.”

column1: Deliveries / Rebalancings / Replenishments counts,Sub-metrics of logistics movements
column2: guide pooling and rebalancing policy decisions.,"Numerical rows in Tables 3–9 (e.g., “Deliveries 18.491 … Rebalancings 0 ...”).  "

column1: Expected annual unprotected faults at O/S,Risk metric when no outstation stock is held
column2: used to justify outstation coverage.,Table 5 row “Expected annual unprotected faults at O/S – 76.53”

column1: Expected annual no-fills at O/S,Failure KPI after implementing outstation stock
column2: shows two-order-of-magnitude reduction.,Table 5 row “Expected annual no-fills at O/S 0.73”

column1: Backfill delivery commitment time,Service-level parameter for replenishing operator on-site stock
column2: varied to study cost impact.,Figure 2 title “Annual Expected Lifecycle Cost vs Backfill Commitment Time” and text in Section 4.3.

column1: Expected annual lifecycle cost (vs backfill time),Composite KPI plotted in Figure 2 to show sensitivity to backfill commitment.,Figure 2 graph and accompanying sentence: “…how … the total lifecycle cost depends on the backfill delivery time.”

Wei et al. 2022 - An Application of Newsvendor Model on Pipe Stringing Operations of a Gas Pipeline Construction Project.pdf
Metric,Usage/Description,Text Evidence

Schedule management of pipe fabrication,Key Performance Indicator (KPI) for the construction project,“…the schedule management of pipe fabrication is regarded as a key performance indicator of the construction project.”

Total cost (per day),Used to compare newsvendor policy with traditional policy,"“…the total cost is $760.13 per day compared to the total cost of the traditional method … which is $1,587.22 per day.”  "
Cost saving (absolute),Dollar amount saved by adopting the newsvendor model,"“the newsvendor model could save the company money by 52.11%…”, “save money for $827.09 per day”  "
Cost saving (percentage),Percentage reduction in cost when using the newsvendor model,“…could save the company money by 52.11% on supply chain and logistics operations.”
Expected cost  g(S*),Performance measure minimized by the model
column2: calculated for optimal base-stock level,"“Accordingly, г(S*) = (100+540)(0.2396)(4.957)=760.13.”  "

column1: Holding cost  (h) / Overage cost,Cost of having excess inventory on site
column2: input to newsvendor objective,“Holding cost = Maintenance cost + Risk cost … h = 100”

column1: Penalty cost  (p) / Stock-out (Underage) cost,Cost of insufficient inventory
column2: includes profit loss and standby fee,“Penalty cost = Profit loss + Standby fee of a working crew … p = 540”

column1: Maintenance cost,"Component of holding cost (site security, barriers, etc.)","“…the maintenance cost includes safety barriers cost, warning signs cost, security cost…”  "
Risk cost,Component of holding cost accounting for theft or damage,"“…The risk cost will emerge when pipes have been stolen, burned, or damaged…”  "
Profit loss,Component of penalty cost when a pipe joint is not welded,“…profit loss is benefit loss when 1 pipe joint has not been welded.”
Standby fee (crew),Component of penalty cost for idle welding crew,“…Standby fee is the cost for a welding crew standing by and doing nothing…”
Welding rate / Quantity of welded pipes per day,Operational performance of welding crew
column2: forms empirical demand distribution,"Table 1 lists daily welded quantities

column1: Mean of demand (μ),Average daily demand used in normal distribution approximation,“…the mean was 19.61…”
Standard deviation of demand (σ),Variability of daily demand used in normal distribution,“…its standard deviation was 4.957.”
Optimal order quantity  S*,Number of pipes that minimizes expected cost,"“Thus, the optimal quantity of pipe supply is 25 pieces per day.”  "
Z-score (Zα),Standardized distance of S* from the mean
column2: used in cost formula,“Zα = (25−19.61)/4.957 = 1.087”

column1: ϕ(Zα) (PDF value),Probability density at Zα
column2: used in expected cost formula,“ϕ(Zα) = ϕ(1.087) = 0.2396”

column1: Demand variable  D,Random variable representing daily pipe requirement,"“Pipe supply Demand of pipe string D ∼ N(19.61, 4.957²).”"
K - Ho et al. 2011 - Policy modeling in risk-driven environment.pdf
Indicator,How it is used in the text,Evidence in the text

Key policy risk indicators (KPI),Monitored predictively to warn policy makers and support policy attention management.,“developing and validating an innovative approach for predictive monitoring of the key policy risk indicators (KPI) that will support policy attention management”
Key attention indicators (KAI),Capture the required performance of a policy during implementation
column2: deviations trigger early-warning alerts.,"“monitoring of policy implementation and execution, in order to help policy makers by early warnings to adapt their policies to meet the required ‘performance’, captured by Key Attention Indicators (KAI)”  "

column1: Indicators (generic set defined by policy maker),Baseline metrics chosen during policy customisation to measure impact and feed results back into the cycle.,"“Indicator assignment (policy maker defines the initial set of parameters on which the impact of action will be measured, and describes the launching set of indicators to be used)”  "

Number of unauthorized parking permissions,Concrete metric proposed in the transport-policy example to judge effectiveness of parking regulations.,“if analysis results show that number of unauthorized parking permissions depends on the parking fee and frequency of checking…”

Number of permission requests,Suggested as a candidate indicator derived from the previous metric to monitor policy impact.,“…then number of permission requests will be candidate indicator for measuring the impact of a particular policy.”
Changes in traffic,Potential outcome metric affected by car-usage regulation
column2: can serve as an indicator of policy impact.,“the change in a local regulation on car usage can imply changes in traffic…”

column1: Taxes,Economic metric that may vary due to policy change and can be monitored as an indicator.,"“…can imply changes in traffic, taxes, and environmental conditions…”  "
Environmental conditions,Environmental quality metric suggested as being influenced by policy and therefore measurable.,"“…changes in traffic, taxes, and environmental conditions…”  "
Estate market (property values),Socio-economic metric listed among possible indicators influenced by transport policy.,“…or even in the estate market.”

External metrics for information sources,Quality/credibility measures used to weight incoming event data and reduce noise in monitoring.,“Trust evaluation based on external metrics for information sources can determine the importance of various incoming signals about events and reduce the ‘measurement noise’.”
Yahya et al. 2016 - Towards a meta-modeling approach for social business process requirements capture.pdf
Medidor,Como é usado no texto (função/objetivo),Evidência textual
Key Performance Indicator (KPI),Mede a realização de metas empresariais e de socialização
column2: base para avaliar a eficácia do SBP,“Key performance indicator : Key concept to measure the achievement of an enterprise goals. These KPIs are closely linked to socialization goals and should be carefully deﬁned.”

column1: KPI Monitor,Define como cada KPI será acompanhado/monitorado ao longo do tempo,“KPI monitor: describes how the different KPIs are monitored.”

Current Value (do KPI),Valor corrente do indicador que mostra o progresso rumo ao objetivo,“Current Value : The current value of a KPI that measures the progress towards the satisfaction of a socialization goal.”
Threshold Value (do KPI),Valor mínimo aceitável
column2: se o KPI ficar abaixo dele o objetivo não é satisfeito,"“Threshold Value : The minimum acceptable value that a KPI may have. If the value of a KPI is less than this threshold, the corresponding goal is not satisﬁed.”"

column1: Target Value (do KPI),Valor‐meta
column2: quando alcançado indica que o objetivo foi atingido,“Target Value : The value that the KPI should have to assume that the corresponding goal is reached.”

column1: Return on Investment (ROI),Estimado a partir dos KPIs para avaliar o retorno financeiro da socialização,“Thanks to these KPIs the value of return on investment can be estimated.”
Advertisement Costs,Exemplo concreto de KPI para medir redução de custos de divulgação,"“In this example, these KPIs include advertisement costs, number of new learners, etc.”"
Number of New Learners,Exemplo concreto de KPI para medir impacto da socialização em novos alunos,"“In this example, these KPIs include advertisement costs, number of new learners, etc.”"
Communication Costs,"Citado como meta de redução e, portanto, medidor de desempenho potencial",“for example to reduce communication or advertisement costs.”
Degree of Achievement of Socialization Goals,Mede o quanto os objetivos de socialização foram alcançados,“measure the degree of achievement of the socialization goals.”
Khanna and Sharma 2017 - Integrating SCM with internet of things - implication on HR management.pdf
metric,how it is used in the text,evidence excerpt
Performance,generic goal to be improved in the supply-chain as a whole,“…transforming supply chain by improving its performance and efficiency.” (Abstract)
Efficiency,generic goal together with performance,“…improving its performance and efficiency.” (Abstract)
Productivity,indicator that CPFR seeks to improve within the IoT context,"“…CPFR, a key metric of productivity in supply chain.” (p.5)  "
Wang et al. 2023 - Empowering facial emotion recognition in service industry – a two-stage convolutional neural network model.pdf
Metric,Usage in the text,Evidence (excerpt from the article)

Accuracy,Overall indicator to compare the performance of different FER models and datasets.,"“its accuracy indicates that the proposed model outperforms existing FER models.” / “its accuracy reaches 86.1%, 95.6%, and 69% respectively.”  "
Precision,Evaluates the proportion of correctly identified positive emotions
column2: reported in equations and comparison tables.,Equation (1) gives the mathematical definition
column3: Table 4 column “Precision (%)”
column4: “Results indicate that the proposed FER model performs particularly well … It improves the precision …”

column1: Recall,Measures how many actual positive emotions are discovered by the model
column2: reported together with precision.,Equation (2)
column3: Table 4 column “Recall (%)”
column4: Table 6 column “Recall (%)”.

column1: F1-Score,Harmonic mean of precision and recall
column2: used to summarise classification quality and to show improvements.,Equation (3)
column3: Table 4 column “F1-Score (%)”
column4: “The proposed model improves by 7.8% in F1-Score as compared to Yolov3.”

column1: mAP (mean Average Precision),Main object-detection measure to evaluate YOLO/ two-stage model over all classes.,Equation (4)
column2: Table 5 column “mAP”
column3: “The overall mAP of the proposed model ranges from 69% to 96% …”

column1: AP (Average Precision),Per-class precision integral
column2: used to build mAP and to analyse which emotions are best recognised.,"Defined in Eq.(4) term APi
column3: Table 5 lists AP per emotion (Happy, Neutral …).  "

column1: TP / FP / TN / FN,Elements of the confusion matrix used as basic counters for all derived metrics.,"Table 1 ‘Confusion matrix for evaluation’ lists TP, FP, TN, FN
column2: Section 3.3 states “The confusion matrix is used as a model verification indicator.”  "

column1: IoU (Intersection-over-Union),Threshold to label training boxes for MTCNN pre-processing.,“The Intersection-over-Union (IoU) ratio of a region compared to a ground truth face less than 0.3 is marked as a negative … If the IoU ratio is between 0.4 and 0.65 …”
Loss,Optimization indicator plotted during training to follow convergence.,Figure 4 shows ‘loss function drops’
column2: “Figure 10. The training and validating loss are around 1 …”

column1: Computational Training Time (hr),"Wall-clock time required to fit the network, used to discuss efficiency.",Table 4 column “Computational Training Time (hr)” (values 12–16 hr)
column2: Table 2(b) lines ‘Run time: 12 hr’.

column1: Computational Testing Time (sec),Time per inference for real-time viability discussion.,Table 4 column “Computational Testing Time (sec)” (0.022–0.034 s).
Run Time,Alternative wording for training time shown while tuning hyper-parameters.,Table 2(b) ‘Run time: 12 hr’ and ‘Run time: 14 hr’ for different parameter sets.
Response Time,"End-to-end latency of a commercial baseline system, used for external comparison.",“Face ID reaches a rapid response time of 0.77 in seconds but without an emotion detection function.”
Improvement Percentage,Derived metric to express relative gain over the baseline model.,Table 6 bottom row ‘Improvement (%) (b)-(a) 5.9% 7.7% 7.8%’
column2: Text: “The proposed model improves by 7.8% in F1-Score …”

column1: Vom Brocke and Seidel 2011 - Lecture Notes in Business Information Processing - Preface.pdf
medidor,como é usado no texto,evidência no texto

Resource efficiency,Indicador ecológico citado como objetivo de melhoria de atividades de negócio suportadas por TI.,“…discuss how BPM approaches can be leveraged to support sustainability and resource efficiency of IT supported business activities.”

Social dimension,Dimensão de desempenho considerada em um método de gestão de desempenho de processos.,"“…process performance management with particular consideration of social, ecological, and economic dimensions.”  "

Ecological dimension,Dimensão de desempenho considerada tanto em métodos de gestão de processos quanto em medições de pegada de carbono.,"1) “…process performance management with particular consideration of social, ecological, and economic dimensions.” 2) “…focus on the ecologic dimension and propose an approach to measure the carbon footprint…”  "

Economic dimension,Dimensão de desempenho considerada em métodos de gestão de processos e na conceituação da sustentabilidade de iniciativas de BPM.,"1) “…process performance management with particular consideration of social, ecological, and economic dimensions.” 2) “…conceptualize the sustainability of BPM initiatives per se, thus focusing on the economic dimension.”  "

Process performance,"Resultado (nível de desempenho) a ser gerido medindo-se dimensões sociais, ecológicas e econômicas.","“…propose an approach to process performance management with particular consideration of social, ecological, and economic dimensions.”  "

Dynamic indicators,Conjunto de métricas utilizado para controlar todos os níveis de arquiteturas empresariais.,“…discuss how dynamic indicators can be used in order to control all levels of enterprise architectures.”

Carbon footprint,Métrica ecológica proposta para quantificar emissões durante a execução de um processo de negócio.,“…propose an approach to measure the carbon footprint caused during the execution of a business process.”

Ecological aspects,Aspectos ambientais incluídos em sistema de medição de desempenho de companhia aérea.,“…discuss the role of ecological and social aspects in the performance measurement of an Ethiopian airline.”

Social aspects,Aspectos sociais incluídos em sistema de medição de desempenho de companhia aérea.,“…discuss the role of ecological and social aspects in the performance measurement of an Ethiopian airline.”

van de Ven 2021 - Designing a method for defining and monitoring business model performance indicators.pdf
medidor_de_performance,uso_no_texto,evidencia

Performance indicators,Indicadores genéricos que devem ser continuamente monitorados para controlar o desempenho do modelo de negócio e acionar redesign quando necessário.,“Business model performance management refers to the continuous monitoring of performance indicators and changes in the environment to control business model performance…”

Business model performance indicators,Indicadores especificamente ligados ao desempenho do modelo de negócio que precisam ser definidos e monitorados.,“…provide little insight or guidance on how business model performance indicators can be defined and monitored.”

Key Performance Indicators (KPIs),Termo genérico para indicadores-chave de desempenho mencionado como parte do vocabulário de pesquisa e como base para gestão de desempenho.,"“keywords for searching the databases are a combination of the terms ‘business model’, ‘performance indicator’, ‘performance metric’, and ‘performance measure’.” (o termo KPI é implicitamente derivado de ‘performance indicator’ e aparece explicitamente no Ref. [26])"

Business model key performance indicators,"KPIs específicos para modelos de negócio, propostos como objeto de definição em pesquisa recente.",“Defining business model key performance indicators using intentional linguistic summaries…” (Ref. [26])

Performance metrics,Métrica usada como sinônimo/derivado de indicador na fase de revisão sistemática da literatura.,"“Potential keywords for searching the databases are a combination of the terms ‘business model’, ‘performance indicator’, ‘performance metric’, and ‘performance measure’.”"
Performance measures,"Outro termo derivado de indicador, considerado na busca por literatura e métodos de mensuração.","idem: “…‘performance metric’, and ‘performance measure’.”"

Process performance indicators,"Indicadores de desempenho de processos, normalmente usados no nível operacional e cuja agregação para o nível tático é proposta.","“…process performance indicators, which are now mainly used at an operational level, by aggregating these to a higher tactical level…”"

Process performance data,Dados brutos de desempenho de processos que podem ser agregados para compor indicadores do modelo de negócio.,“process performance data may not always be directly mappable to business models because a complex relationship exists…”

Operational performance,"Dimensão de desempenho operacional da empresa, gerada pelos processos e potencialmente agregável ao modelo de negócio.",“…processes of a company produce a wealth of data and information about the operational performance of a company.”

Financial performance,"Indicador financeiro que hoje domina o monitoramento prático de modelos de negócio, mas é considerado limitado.",“most business model monitoring efforts in practice are limited to monitoring financial performance.”

Performance estimation,Estimativa de desempenho como técnica/medida aplicada a modelos de negócio em rede.,“Performance estimation of networked business models: case study on a Finnish eHealth Service Project.” (Ref. [23])
Business model metrics,"Conjunto de métricas voltadas a modelos de negócio, mencionado como repositório aberto de indicadores.",“Business model metrics: an open repository.” (Ref. [22])

column1: nqc,STij,Valor de QoS normalizado de um sub-tarefa

column1: nqc,Pi,"QoS de cada processo, obtido agregando nqc,STij

column1: nqc,WP,QoS médio em todo o conjunto de processos

column1: TQoS,Desempenho geral de QoS dos múltiplos processos (métrica principal)

column1: Ṅqc,STij (threshold),Limite mínimo de QoS exigido para cada sub-tarefa

column1: TSR,Grau de atendimento global dos requisitos especiais
column2: objetivo secundário.,"Eq.(4) “TSR = ( Σi Σl nPi,l / |SRSTPi| ) / m.”"

column1: EoBN_WP,Entropia do tipo de Node no conjunto de processos
column2: mede caos de marcas.,"Eq.(7) “EoBNWP = – ΣTN PWP,TN ln(PWP,TN).”"

column1: SCF_WP,Consistência normalizada de Node em múltiplos processos
column2: parte de TSC.,Eq.(6) “SCFWP = (EoBNmaxWP – EoBNWP) / EoBNmaxWP.”

column1: CEoBN_Pi,Entropia de Node modificada pelo efeito cumulativo em um processo
column2: parte de SCF_Pi.,"Eq.(10) – primeira linha “CEoBNPi = – ΣTN (1– ΣCoTN cuePi,CoTN) PPi,TN ln(PPi,TN).”"

column1: CEoBS_Pi,Entropia de Side modificada com efeito cumulativo
column2: parte de SCF_Pi.,Eq.(10) – segunda linha.

column1: cuePi,CoTN / cuePi,CoTS,Efeito cumulativo contínuo de agregação de nós/arestas iguais
column2: afeta CEoBN e CEoBS.,"Eq.(11) “cuePi,CoTN = (e^(PPi,CoTN ln2) –1)^λNode …”"

column1: SCF_Pi,Consistência (Node+Side) de um processo

column1: SCF_AEP,Média das consistências de todos os processos
column2: componente de TSC.,Eq.(8) “SCFAEP = ( Σi SCFPi ) / m.”

column1: TSC,Score global de consistência de serviços em múltiplos processos.,Eq.(5) “TSC = (SCFWP + SCFAEP)/2.”
TOTAL Score,Função objetivo principal = ω1*TQoS + ω2*TSR + ω3*TSC
column2: métrica a ser maximizada.,“Max Score = ω1 TQoS + ω2 TSR + ω3 TSC.”

column1: Fit(x),Valor de aptidão de um gene (solução) usado no algoritmo

column1: F_P(x),Aptidão penalizada por violação de restrições de QoS

column1: Kress and Seese 2010 - Autonomous optimization of business processes.pdf
Metric,Usage in the text,Evidence from the text

Key Performance Indicators (KPIs),Generic term for the performance measures to be optimised by the agents and used in the fitness function.,"“…the objective to optimise the Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) under consideration of the operating conditions.” / “The simulation calculates KPIs such as cycle time, throughput, costs, among others.”  "
Cycle time,"Main KPI
column2: constrained in Eq. 1, monitored during experiments, target of the SLA.","“…meanCT the average cycle time which has to be less than a specific number of time units, here 1200.” / “The simulation calculates KPIs such as cycle time, throughput, costs, among others.” / Table 2 columns ‘Mean Cycle Time’.  "

column1: Throughput,Additional KPI produced by the simulation component.,"“The simulation calculates KPIs such as cycle time, throughput, costs, among others.”  "
Costs (mean costs/average costs),KPI to be minimised
column2: calculated from processing times and reported in experiments.,“minimize meanC” / “The costs of executing a business process are determined on the basis of the processing times…” / Table 2 columns ‘Mean Costs’.

column1: Service Level Agreement (SLA) on cycle time,Constraint that cycle time must stay below a threshold while minimising costs.,“…minimisation of the costs by assuring a specific service level agreement regarding the cycle time.”
Processing times,Basic performance measure per task
column2: basis for cost calculation and simulation inputs.,“It also determines the task processing times based on a gamma distribution or constant values.” / “The costs of executing a business process are determined on the basis of the processing times…”

column1: Waiting times,Indicator of queueing
column2: mentioned when arrival rate is lowered to study performance.,“…a lower arrival rate is selected in such a way that waiting times occur but the RAs are still able to execute the arriving EPMs.”

column1: Workload information,Runtime measure used by policy rules to choose variants and schedule work.,"“Rule (1) requests work load information if it is not available…” / “If work load information is available, it is used in the calculation of the estimated duration.”  "
Estimated execution duration,Derived performance estimate used to compare variants in policy rules.,“Rule (4) activates the variant with the shortest estimated execution duration…”
Fitness value,Scalar performance indicator returned by each simulation run to PSO
column2: based on KPIs.,“Result of this simulation is the fitness value.”

column1: Arrival rate,Performance-related input parameter varied in the scenarios and simulation.,“Constant arrival rate of 1000 minutes.” / “…a lower arrival rate is selected in such a way that waiting times occur…”

Communication overhead (time units),Performance overhead of the MAS taken into account in simulations.,“This overhead is 4 time units for each executed production rule… The request of workload information requires additionally 2 time units.”
Valente et al. 2022 - Interpretability, personalization and reliability of a machine learning based clinical decision support system.pdf
Metric,Usage_in_Text,Evidence_in_Text
Accuracy,General term for predictive performance of models
column2: discussed as trade-off with interpretability,“Research on explainable AI typically faces a trade-off between ML interpretability and performance (Tjoa and Guan 2015).”

column1: Sensitivity (SE),Used to quantify the true-positive rate in binary classification
column2: formally defined in Eq. 1 and later applied in GM and rule–threshold optimisation,“SE = TP / (TP + FN) (1)”

column1: Specificity (SP),Used to quantify the true-negative rate in binary classification
column2: formally defined in Eq. 2 and later applied in GM and rule–threshold optimisation,“SP = TN / (TN + FP) (2)”

column1: Geometric Mean (GM),Chosen single–operating-point metric for imbalanced data
column2: maximised to choose optimal rule thresholds and reported to compare models,"“…the geometric mean (GM) … is selected as the criterion to be maximized.”  /  “Considering the obtained results, the proposed procedure showed to perform very well … in terms of … GM.”"

column1: GM² (square of GM),Mathematical derivative used to avoid square-root in optimisation of rule thresholds,"“…to avoid the squared root operator, the square of the GM was considered as the value to be maximized.”"
F1 Score,Mentioned as alternative single–point metric for imbalanced data,"“…other metrics, like the geometric mean and the F1 score.”"
Area Under the ROC Curve (AUC),"Global discrimination metric widely used in clinical studies
column2: employed to compare proposed model, ANN and GRACE","“…a typical alternative to a global operating measure … is the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC).”  /  “Table 4 presents AUC … for the proposed approach, ANN and GRACE.”"

column1: Deep ROC Analysis,Enhanced ROC-based evaluation providing interpretation across risk groups
column2: cited as useful in explainable AI context,“…the deep ROC analysis. This method is especially relevant … since it can provide interpretation and assurance for patients in each risk group…”

column1: Predictive Accuracy (P),"Part of the PDR framework, one of three proposed interpretability metrics","“introduced the PDR framework, consisting of three distinct metrics … predictive accuracy (P), descriptive accuracy (D), and relevancy (R).”"
Descriptive Accuracy (D),Second element of PDR interpretability framework,same citation as above
Relevancy (R),Third element of PDR interpretability framework involving human assessment,same citation as above

Stability,Proposed quantitative component of interpretability (with predictive performance and simplicity),"“…interpretability concept, based on three individual metrics … predictive performance, stability and simplicity.”"
Simplicity,Another quantitative component of interpretability
column2: part of Margot (2020) proposal,same citation as above

column1: System Causability Scale (SCS),Metric to measure the quality of explanations/human-AI interface,"“…the System Causability Scale, a simple and efficient assessment tool capable to measure the quality of an explanation interface…”"
Calibration Curve / Calibration Slope & Intercept,Used to assess how predicted probabilities align with observed outcomes
column2: plotted to compare models in Fig. 10,“The latter shows how the mortality rate varies with the predicted mortality risk in the validation group.”

column1: Misclassification Rate,Percentage of incorrectly classified cases
column2: analysed against reliability estimates in Fig. 11,“…misclassification rate corresponds to the percentage of patients who were incorrectly classified…”

column1: Balanced Average Accuracy,Named as another interpretation of AUC in deep ROC context
column2: referred to model selection and interpretation,“…Deep ROC analysis and AUC as balanced average accuracy to improve model selection…”

column1: Permutation Feature Importance,"A global model-agnostic explanation metric
column2: although not a discrimination metric, it measures model performance degradation when features are permuted","“Permutation Feature Importance … are instances of such methods, based on the relative importance assessment of each feature for the output prediction.”"

Error Rate,Avaliar a precisão das previsões de tempo de entrega.,“error rate of less than 5% for delivery time forecasts.”

Coeficiente de Determinação (R²),Medir o quão bem o modelo explica a variância nos tempos de entrega.,"“coefficient of determination (R^2) very close to 1, meaning that the model explains almost all the variance in delivery times.”"
Tempo de Detecção de Anomalias,Avaliar a rapidez com que anomalias são identificadas.,“significant reduction in anomaly detection times compared to traditional approaches.”

Tempo de Entrega,"Métrica principal prevista, comparada e analisada (distribuição, histograma, comparação real × previsto).","“delivery time forecasts”, “distribution of delivery times”, “predicted and actual delivery times.”"
Tempo de Execução,Indicador previsto para monitorar duração de processos.,“predict indicators such as execution time…”
Probabilidade de Não Conformidade,Indicador previsto para alertar sobre possíveis violações de conformidade.,“…or the likelihood of non-compliance.”
Quantidade Total em Estoque,Snapshot cumulativo usado como exemplo de métrica operacional.,“record the total quantity in stock at the end of each day.”
Saldos Financeiros,Exemplo de KPI cumulativo analisado em determinados momentos.,“…such as financial balances or key performance indicators (KPIs).”
KPIs (Indicadores-Chave de Performance),Conjunto geral de métricas usadas para avaliar desempenho do processo.,“…key performance indicators (KPIs).”
Rastreamento de SLA,Monitorar cumprimento de acordos de nível de serviço.,“…such as bottleneck detection or SLA (Service Level Agreement) tracking.”
Taxa de Entrega no Prazo (OTD),KPI operacional melhorado por previsões precisas.,“operational KPIs such as on-time delivery (OTD) rates…”
Taxa de Devoluções de Clientes,Métrica de qualidade e satisfação do cliente.,“…customer return rates…”
Custo Logístico por Unidade,Indicador de eficiência de custos na cadeia logística.,“…logistics cost per unit.”
Margem de Lucro,Avaliar rentabilidade impactada por redução de atrasos/custos.,“lead to increased profit margins…”
Fluxo de Caixa,Métrico financeiro beneficiado por melhor previsão e eficiência.,“…improved cash flow…”
Gestão de Ativos,Indicador financeiro-operacional melhorado por uso de recursos.,“…better asset management.”
Retorno sobre Investimento (ROI),KPI financeiro para avaliar ganhos versus investimentos.,“return on investment (ROI)…”
COGS (Custo dos Bens Vendidos),Indicador de custo diretamente afetado por eficiência operacional.,“…cost of goods sold (COGS)…”
Lucratividade Operacional,Mede ganhos operacionais após custos diretos.,“…operational profitability.”
Tempo Total de Processamento,Métrica analisada via tabela fato cumulativa para entender eficiência.,“…total processing time…”
Custos Associados,Medida de custos totais ligados às etapas do processo.,“…associated costs…”
Eckert et al. 2008 - Queuing-based capacity planning approach for Web service workflows using optimization algorithms.pdf
Metric,Usage in Text,Evidence from the Paper
Arrival rate (λ),Measures the average number of incoming workflow/service requests per unit of time
column2: forms the input of each queue and is used to compute utilisation and stability.,"""The M/M/1 queuing model assumes that the arrivals are distributed in a Poisson manner … with the arrival rate λ."" "

column1: Service rate (μ),"Measures how many requests a Web service can process per unit of time
column2: combined with λ to calculate utilisation, throughput and the stable-state condition.","""… service times are also negatively exponentially distributed … where μ denotes the rate at which the jobs are processed."" "

column1: Utilisation (ρ),Ratio λ / μ that expresses how much of the service capacity is used
column2: central indicator for overload avoidance and the main value to be maximised in the optimisation.,"""The utilisation ρ_i of the server i can be calculated as shown in equation 3… This implies that the system (server) can only be in stable state if ρ_i ≤ 1."" "

column1: Average number of customers in system (N),Expected number of requests simultaneously waiting or being served at one Web service
column2: derived from ρ and used to estimate queue length.,"""The average number of customers N in the system … yields to: N = ρ / (1−ρ)."" "

column1: Average system / response time (T),Average time a request spends in queue plus service at one Web service
column2: computed as 1 / (μ − λ) and used as a performance constraint.,"""The average system time T is the time a job spends in the system (queue and server) … T = 1 / (μ − λ)."" "

column1: Throughput (γ),Rate of completed requests leaving a Web service
column2: in a stable M/M/1 equals the arrival rate and is used to analyse workflow throughput.,"""… the throughput, respectively output γ in the long run … will be the same as the input rate λ, i.e. γ = λ."" "

column1: Overall average response time (T_w),Sum of the average response times of all Web services in the sequential workflow
column2: constrained by a maximum value to guarantee QoS.,"""In a sequential workflow the overall average response time T_w can be calculated by the summation of all average response times T_i,j of all invoked Web services…"" "

column1: Overall queue length (N_w),Sum of the average numbers of customers over all Web services
column2: indicates the total amount of buffering the controller must provide and is limited by a constraint.,"""… the number of jobs the workflow controller has to store … denoted by N_w that is shown in equation (11)."" "

column1: Overall workflow cost (C_w),Aggregated monetary cost of invoking the selected Web services
column2: treated as a constraint in the optimisation model.,"""The computation of the overall costs C_w for the entire workflow execution can be done by the summation of all costs for each invoked Web service … equation (9)."""

column1: Espinosa et al. 2004 - One step beyond - Making B2B decisions with business activity monitoring and soccer.pdf
Indicador,Como é usado no texto,Evidência no texto
Profit (PS),Componente positivo na fórmula de recompensa (Reward)
column2: extraído do BAM para avaliar desempenho financeiro de cada agente/ação.,"""profit (PS) commissions by sales agents (CM) general expenses (EX) cost of passives (CS) and indicators on service vs. support (BL)… serve for the purpose of calculating reward""  "

column1: Commissions (CM),Componente negativo da recompensa
column2: representa custo de vendas por agente.,"""commissions by sales agents (CM)… serve for the purpose of calculating reward""  "

column1: General Expenses (EX),Componente negativo da recompensa
column2: inclui gastos operacionais gerais.,"""general expenses (EX)… serve for the purpose of calculating reward""  "

column1: Cost of Passives (CS),Componente negativo da recompensa
column2: custo financeiro de passivos/inventário.,"""cost of passives (CS)… serve for the purpose of calculating reward""  "

column1: Balance service/support (BL),Componente positivo da recompensa
column2: mede qualidade de serviço/suporte.,"""indicators on service vs. support (BL)… serve for the purpose of calculating reward""  "

column1: Reward (r),"Indicador agregado que resume o quão frutífera foi uma combinação de PS, CM, EX, CS, BL
column2: usado para escolher a melhor ação/agente.","""Reward means how fruitful a given combination of factors (PS, CM, EX, CS, BL) have been after a series of business processes have been executed""  "

column1: Utility,Parte da função de decisão Q-Learning (Utility – Risk + Positioning)
column2: representa ganho esperado de uma ação.,"""…calculation based on a risk vs. utility Q-Learning positioning function, as shown on (1).""  "

column1: Risk,Termo subtraído da Utility na função Q-Learning
column2: mede incerteza/perigo associado à ação.,"""U(BA,a_i)=Utility(BA,a_i) - Risk(BA,a_i) + Positioning(BA,a_i) (1)""  "

column1: Positioning,Termo positivo da função Q-Learning
column2: avalia quão bem o agente está posicionado para executar a ação.,"""…utility(BA,a_i) - Risk(BA,a_i) + Positioning(BA,a_i) (1)""  "

column1: Number of successful orders,#successful orders aparece em relatórios estratégicos como métrica de produtividade de cada agente.,"""agent: Sally, #successful orders: 23, reward: 18""  "
PS-CM,Indicador derivado (lucro líquido por venda)
column2: exibido em relatórios estratégicos.,"""agent Joe, PS-CM=15…""  "

column1: EX+CS,Indicador derivado (soma de despesas e custos de passivos)
column2: exibido em relatórios estratégicos.,"""agent Joe, PS-CM=15, EX+CS=17…"""

column1: Wang et al. 2015 - Multi-objects scalable coordinated learning in internet of things.pdf
Medidor,Como é usado no texto,Evidência no texto

Confiabilidade (Reliability),Avalia a execução de tarefas de coordenação dinâmica levando em conta a razão de mensagens de serviço enviadas/recebidas corretamente mesmo com nós maliciosos.,"“Figure 4 shows the paradigms reliability of dynamic coordination task… system reliability… is calculated according to the correctly send and received service information, when cooperative team exist in baleful nodes.”  "
Eficiência (Efficiency),Mede o ganho quando objetos confiáveis participam
column2: baseada também em mensagens corretas enviadas/recebidas.,“Figure 5 shows the another paradigms efficiency… enthusiasm of trustful smart objects participating… calculated according to the correctly send and received service information.”

column1: Escalabilidade (Scalability),"Avalia se o sistema mantém desempenho (latência de mensagens, nº de saltos, sobrecarga de comunicação) quando o número de tarefas/nós cresce.","“Two experiments … are to show the scalability, and efficiency service of smart agriculture in dynamic coordination environment… the more are the hops that packets have to perform … the less the scalability of the message reception.”  "

Disponibilidade (Availability),Probabilidade de o serviço permanecer ativo quando objetos falham ou são removidos do cluster.,“The line model 1 shows the probability that the service is available without fail-over capability… scalable coordinated learning had the probabilities of 77.2 % … when 52 out of 60 objects … were removed.”
Robustez (Robustness),Capacidade do serviço continuar operando sob falhas
column2: comparada a modelos com/sem fail-over.,“Figure 6 shows more capable of enhancing service robustness than the system without fail-over capability…”

column1: Utilidade Global (Global Performance / Utility),Meta de otimização para todo o sistema
column2: soma das utilidades das tarefas concluídas.,“The coordinated multi-objects system enables a group of autonomous objects … in order to optimize a global performance measure.”

column1: Recompensa (Reward),Valor imediato que cada objeto recebe após executar uma ação
column2: componente do cálculo de utilidade.,"“Ri provides objects i with an individual reward ri(s,a) for taking action a in state s.”  "

column1: Klaus 2000 - What is ERP.pdf
Medidor,Como é usado no texto,Evidência extraída do texto
Eficiência (Efficiency),Indicador de desempenho técnico
column2: o texto afirma que avaliar a performance (eficiência) de um ERP é mais complexo do que sua efetividade.,“...é muitas vezes mais complicado avaliar a performance (eficiência) do ERP do que a sua efetividade (does it support the required functionality?).”

column1: Efetividade (Effectiveness),Usada em contraste com eficiência para verificar se o sistema atende às funcionalidades requeridas.,Mesma passagem: “...avaliar a performance (eficiência) do ERP do que a sua efetividade (does it support the required functionality?).”

Gestão de desempenho em tempo hábil (Timely performance management),Citada como foco gerencial impulsionando a evolução do ERP.,Tabela 3 (dinâmicas gerenciais): “Focus on timely performance management and ‘balanced scorecard’ approach.”

Balanced Scorecard,Proposto como abordagem estruturada para medir o desempenho do ERP e seus benefícios.,“Measuring the Performance of ERP Software: A Balanced Scorecard Approach (Rosemann & Wiese 1999).”  ‑ e  “Tabela 3 ... ‘balanced scorecard’ approach.”
Benefícios Organizacionais,Avaliação/medição dos ganhos obtidos com o ERP
column2: vários estudos procuram ‘maximizar’ ou ‘mensurar’ esses benefícios.,"“...fazer recomendações sobre como maximizar os benefícios do ERP (Niehus, Knobel et al., 1998).”  "

column1: Qualidade,Apontada como um dos ganhos de desempenho prometidos pelos sistemas ERP.,"“...benefits from increased efficiency to improved quality, productivity, and profitability...”  "
Produtividade (Productivity),Idem qualidade
column2: incluída na lista de benefícios de desempenho esperados.,"Mesma passagem: “...increased efficiency to improved quality, productivity, and profitability...”  "

column1: Lucratividade (Profitability),Indicador financeiro chave prometido como resultado da adoção de ERP.,"Mesma passagem: “...improved quality, productivity, and profitability.”  "

Satisfação do Cliente (Customer Satisfaction),Objetivo de desempenho corporativo que motivou a ampliação de MRP II para ERP.,“...companies quickly realized that profitability and customer satisfaction are objectives that apply to the entire enterprise...”

Análise Custo/Benefício (Cost/Benefit Analysis),Apontada como um dos cinco grandes ‘issues’ a serem enfrentados para obter valor estratégico de sistemas ERP.,"Laudon & Laudon (2000): “implementation, cost/benefit analysis, robustness, interoperability and the realization of strategic value.”  "
Robustez (Robustness),Citada como critério de avaliação de desempenho/qualidade dos sistemas ERP.,Mesma lista de Laudon & Laudon (2000) menciona “robustness”.

medidor,uso,evidencia

Confiabilidade (Reliability),Atributo-chave de desempenho do SCOR para monitorar os processos da cadeia de suprimentos de manutenção.,"“In SCOR, each process has its performance metrics to monitor overall supply chain performance which attributes: Reliability, Responsiveness, Agility, Cost, and Assets management efficiency.”  "
Responsividade (Responsiveness),Outro atributo de desempenho do SCOR utilizado como métrica de avaliação dos processos.,Idem citação anterior.
Agilidade (Agility),Atributo de desempenho do SCOR que mede a capacidade de resposta rápida a mudanças na cadeia de serviços.,Idem citação anterior.
Custo (Cost),Métrica SCOR para controlar e otimizar os gastos da cadeia de manutenção.,Idem citação anterior.
Eficiência na Gestão de Ativos (Assets management efficiency),Mede o uso de ativos na cadeia de serviços de manutenção segundo o SCOR.,Idem citação anterior.
Eficácia (Effectiveness),Utilizada para validar os modelos propostos de manutenção (qualidade dos resultados).,“validate the effectiveness of models”
Viabilidade (Feasibility),Critério de avaliação do método: verifica se o modelo pode ser seguido na prática.,“Feasibility: Can the adapted model be followed?”

Usabilidade (Usability),Critério de avaliação do método: facilidade de uso e aplicação dos passos e técnicas.,“Usability: Is the adapted model workable? Are the steps and techniques easy to use and apply?”

Utilidade (Usefulness),Critério de avaliação do método: valor gerado para a organização pelo modelo desenvolvido.,“Usefulness: Is the adopted model worth following? Does the model produce results that the business finds helpful?”
Nível de Serviço (Service level),Indicador de desempenho que se pretende elevar com o novo modelo de manutenção.,“the model can be improved service level”
Redução de Quebras / Falhas (Breakdown reduction),Mede a diminuição de falhas nos simuladores após a implantação do modelo.,“reduce the breakdown”

Satisfação do Cliente (Customer satisfaction),Meta de desempenho mencionada como objetivo da operação do centro de treinamento.,"“provide quality service, to achieve the highest customer satisfaction”  "

Desempenho dos Dispositivos (Device performance),"Indicador que deve atender aos regulamentos internacionais (EASA, ICAO, FAA).",“flight simulator operator has to ensure that the performance of the devices qualified with the international regulations”

MAE (Mean Absolute Error),Utilizado como indicador-chave para medir a diferença média absoluta entre valores previstos e reais
column2: componente central da avaliação de desempenho do modelo.,"""We introduce the mean absolute error (MAE) as the key performance indicator of our prediction model (Formula 2). MAE provides a straightforward measure of the average size of the error between our model’s predictions and actual revenue data…"""

column1: RMSE (Root Mean Square Error),Empregado para avaliar o desempenho do modelo dando penalidade maior a erros grandes
